speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to urge the government to introduce as soon as possible the much awaited legislation concerning the merchant mariners.
These men fought valiantly under the most extreme conditions, giving their lives to preserve the democratic institutions of our country. Merchant mariners lived through hell. They suffered the highest death rate of any group in the second war. About 1,150 were killed while bringing troops and supplies to Europe between 1939 and 1945, and today they are dying at a rate of one every two days.
They deserve to be recognized as full veterans in their lifetimes so that they may receive the benefits attendant with this status. I believe that such benefits-nursing care, transportation, housekeeping and other services- would help to slow down the high mortality rate.
This is the least we can do for those who were denied this recognition throughout their lifetimes. It is the least that we can do to honour those who died before this honour could be bestowed upon them.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to draw the House's attention to the major findings of the Conference Board of Canada study called Dropping Out: The Cost to Canada.
The federal Stay In School initiative stresses that the young person's success in the work force depends on getting that high school diploma. This study, which was funded under the federal Stay In School initiative, backs that up. The report findings show, for example, that
137,000 high school students who dropped out instead of graduating with the class of 1989 will cost Canada $4 billion during their working lives in lost productivity and tax revenue and higher social welfare costs.
At the same time, the study shows that a young person earns a good return from the time and money devoted to gaining a high school education. The study puts that rate of return for male students at 65.4 per cent and for female students at 74.4 per cent.
This study is critically important, underscoring as it does the enormous cost to all Canadians of even one young person dropping out of school.

Employees at the Health Protection Branch of the Department of National Health and Welfare have once again blown the whistle on their superiors, including the minister of health.
An internal memorandum dated April 27, and signed by no fewer than 18 physicians at the Bureau of Human Prescription Drugs, criticizes the continuing removal of medically qualified personnel at the higher levels of the drug approval process.
The memo says this will, and I quote:
-interfere with the bureau's mandate to ensure the safety and efficiency of drugs and may also jeopardize the health of Canadians participating in clinical studies.
Concerns about the operation of the Health Protection Branch are not new. There have been serious allegations about the approval of the Meme breast implant. The government must move to restore the confidence Canadians must have in this important regulatory agency by ordering a public inquiry into the organization and operation of the Health Protection Branch.

Mr. Speaker, next week Canadians of Chinese origin are coming to Parliament Hill seeking long overdue redress for the Chinese exclusion act and the head tax.
Between 1885 and 1923 Canada imposed a head tax of up to $500 on all Chinese immigrants while at the same time providing financial assistance to other immigrants. In 1923 this House passed the Chinese Immigration (Exclusion) Act which prohibited illiterates, diseased persons, beggars, vagrants, idiots, epileptics, and persons of Chinese origin from entering Canada. No wonder Canadians of Chinese origin want redress.
The Progressive Conservative Party of Canada is on record since 1984 as supporting redress.
Last week the Prime Minister said he would be happy to meet representatives of multicultural or visible minority groups to see how we can improve on the good record of Canada and build a better society. Next week he will have the opportunity with Canadians of Chinese origin.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday's statistics on taxation confirm what we have been saying all along, that the government's policies have come at the expense of the working people and the wealthy have escaped relatively unscathed.
We can now add seniors to the list of the government's victims. Just last month one of my constituents received a letter from Health and Welfare advising her she was being audited for a period going back 12 years. The letter stated that because she received 87 cents more per month than she was entitled to, she now owes the government money, with compound interest of course.
Does this government have no morals? The incorrect assessment was its mistake and now its is breaking its own laws by going back 12 years for an audit. What is the cost of this harassment? To our seniors it causes unnecessary stress and hardship and to the taxpayer a warped definition of government efficiency.
First we had the clawback to old age security payments, then the announcement of the meagre 37 cent increase per month in payments to our seniors, and now illegal intimidation tactics that prey on fear and ignorance.
We were wrong all along when we stated this government is morally bankrupt because for 87 cents-
The hon. member's time has expired.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, a campaign to promote student employment and private initiatives was launched on May 8 across the country. This 24-year old tradition has helped students earn money to pay for their tuition fees and gives them personal satisfaction. I may add it also strengthens their determination to succeed in their studies. All these factors are essential to Canada's economic growth.
The student placement service, which operates through 400 centres, is seen as a way to help the next generation of workers join the labour force, and I urge all employers to do their share.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the New Democratic Party in this House claims to be the self-appointed creator and saviour of Canada's social safety net even though it has never held office. Its true colours are being exposed in Ontario where it has been elected.
What is the record? Tkx cuts for corporations are announced in their budget while their federal colleagues who are out of office call for increases. Cuts in health care while their federal cousins call for no reductions. Increases in personal income taxes while their federal brothers and sisters call for tax breaks. Cancellation of projects that make liars out of more than one of their ministers.
May 13, 1992

Is this the kind of NDP government we would expect in Ottawa if that party wins a federal election? NDP hypocrites? Surely not.

Mr. Speaker, last Monday while opposition members here tried to blame free trade for unemployment and declining investment, outside in the real world Kraft General Foods was announcing a $74 million expansion this year so its plants at Scarborough and Cobourg, in Ontario, and LaSalle and Mount Royal, in Quebec, can supply the entire U.S. market.
Company president Doug Smith tied this expansion directly to the success of the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, extolling it as "on balance-a good deal for Canada". He pointed out how Canada's trade balance with the U.S. has jumped by billions of dollars each year since free trade began, reaching a 1991 surplus of $16 billion in our favour.
While one perhaps should not crow about such things, it is a fact that just last week Kraft General Foods announced a reduction of 1,000 jobs in the United States. That is positive proof of how capably our workers and industries can compete.
I am afraid the hon. member's time has expired.

Mr. Speaker, the hearts of all members of this House go out to the grieving families, friends and workmates of those miners, now 14 in number, who have lost their lives as a result of the tragic events at the Westray mine.
There are obviously serious questions that must be asked at the appropriate time-that time is not now- about the events that led to this terrible disaster.
In order that the public interest may be served with due regard to the feelings and discomfort of the aggrieved families and others in the community, I hope
that this government will see its way clear, of its own volition to provide this House at the earliest appropriate opportunity with all studies and documentation concerning its involvement with the Westray mining operation.
We may then all fulfil our obvious obligations with a maximum degree of dignity and respect for those most personally concerned. Meanwhile, we all hope and pray that those miners remaining underground will be found alive and well.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, from June 3 to June 14, the nations of the world will meet in Rio for the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, the earth summit.
It will be one of the largest global gatherings in history, bringing together over 100 world leaders, including President George Bush and Prime Minister Brian Mul-roney.
The earth summit marks the first time in history that nations of the world will tackle in the same meeting two pressing needs, namely the protection of the water, atmosphere and other environmental systems which make life possible on earth and economic development.
Given the magnitude of the problems facing our planet, I am sure all members of the House join me in applauding the decision of President George Bush to participate in this monumental gathering in Rio.
In the end, we will all have to change our attitudes, our way of thinking and our way of acting on common global problems. I for one believe the announcement of President Bush's attendance at the earth summit is a major step in that direction.

Mr. Speaker, following the successful conclusion of general elections in the Philippines last weekend, I am certain that all members of this House are greatly encouraged by the fact that one more step has been taken on the long road to democracy.

May 13, 1992
Oral Questions
Although final results are not expected until an estimated 28 million votes are fully tabulated over the next few days, the president-elect of the Philippines will require our co-operation to continue social and economic reforms.
In the years since the fall of the Marcos regime, Canada has proven to be a generous friend to the Philippines, but much more remains to be done.
Natural disasters continue to plague progress and therefore I, together with my constituents of Filipino descent, call on the government to maintain Canada's assistance to help rebuild the critical infrastructure which supports democracy in the Philippines.

Mr. Speaker, mining communities in Abitibi were appalled by the terrible disaster at the Westray mine in Nova Scotia.
These communities join me in extending sincere condolences to the families of eleven fellow miners who perished in this accident.
This disaster makes us reflect on the hazards faced daily by miners across this country. It reminds us that those who do this kind of work deserve our admiration and respect.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Prime Minister, but in his absence, I will direct it to the Acting Prime Minister.
Over a year ago the Liberal Party suggested that a national referendum be held, a referendum that should require a majority of all Canadians and a majority in each of Canada's four regions: in the Atlantic region, Quebec, Ontario and Western Canada.
Can the government give the House the assurance that if in a referendum one of Canada's regions were to vote no, the government would give up its plan? [English]

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. Leader of the Opposition knows, what is
being proposed is enabling legislation for a plebiscite. It is a means of consulting the people of Canada. It is not a binding referendum because our Constitution can only be changed according to the rules that exist in the Constitution.
The question of what constitutes a win or not is in a sense irrelevant because we still have the existing constitutional amending formula.
In any case, the decision as to whether there will be a plebiscite or not, the decision as to what question will be asked, is not something the government is prepared to go into now. The Prime Minister has indicated that prior to any such thing there would obviously have to be consultations with all interested parties, including the opposition.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, a referendum is not just a poll. The Canadian people have the right to know what the government will do with the results of this referendum.
Hear, hear.

What we are doing at this moment is making it very clear to the people of Canada that if one part of Canada says no, the Parliament of Canada will not proceed.
My supplementary question is for the House leader. We would like to know why this government has decided not to put any limit on spending. Another surprise is that it is supported by the NDP.
What is important is making sure that we have a fair referendum and that the votes are not-
Hear, hear.

-bought but that the votes are earned.
Will the government accept amendments to make sure that the referendum is a fair one and that there will be limits on spending?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in answering the first question from the Leader of the Opposition, I tried to make it clear, but perhaps I did not explain myself properly, that what we are all seeking is constitutional change that will unite this country. I am sure the leader of the Liberal Party feels the same way.
May 13, 1992

To get that constitutional change requires the approval of the House of Commons, the Senate, and seven provinces representing 50 per cent of the population at least. Some items require unanimity. That is what we are all striving for.
A plebiscite on this issue cannot change the fundamental fact of what is required. That is what we are seeking. A plebiscite may be useful for that purpose, for achieving the goal of unifying the country. It may not. That will be looked at.
So far as spending limits or any other requirements such as umbrella committees are concerned, the advice that we have from legal counsel is that this would be contrary to the charter of rights.
But let me say in answer to the Leader of the Opposition that of course we are willing to consider improvements to the enabling legislation, provided it is allowed under our Constitution.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, how did the government come to the conclusion that it is illegal to limit the expenditures in a public consultation?
We have passed laws in this Parliament for years and in an election every political party is limited in the number of dollars it can spend. Why does the government want to have a referendum that will be perceived as unfair by the people of Canada and particularly in Quebec when it should make sure that the tradition and the rules that prevail in general elections will be followed in a referendum?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member knows, the rules governing a general election have been successfully challenged before the courts. They are under appeal now but they have been challenged.
The hon. Leader of the Opposition, as a former justice minister, is suggesting that whatever we are told by law officers of the Crown, we should say to the Department of Justice that it is wrong and we will do this anyway.
Oral Questions
I hear his seatmate shouting from her seat to table the legal documents in this regard. When the bill is brought forward, these kinds of things will debated and discussed. At committee stage the legal advice that the deputy leader of the Liberal Party is seeking will be given.
I hope that at that time, which is the appropriate point in time, the Liberal Party will agree that we must comply with the charter of rights.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to remind the hon. minister that to give legitimacy to a referendum, it has to be fair and it has to be perceived to be fair. Canadians do not think it is fair when well funded groups can spend as much money as they want to try to influence the outcome.
I want to ask the government House leader if he can assure the House that before tabling any legislation in this House it will contain a provision therein which will have something with regard to reasonable limits of spending? Can he give us that assurance?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as has been explained to the hon. member in discussions we have had with officials from the Privy Council Office, the chief legal advisor to the Privy Council explained to the hon. member that the charter of rights puts constraints on what can and cannot be done.
I absolutely agree it would be futile and damaging to suggest that we would have a plebiscite that could be accused of being unfair and manipulative.
I remind the hon. member that what we are discussing, rather inappropriately, is potential legislation that will make it possible to have a plebiscite. It is not a commitment to have one. There is no indication of what question will be put to the Canadian public. It is only enabling legislation. Again I repeat, the enabling legislation must satisfy the charter of rights and if a decision is taken on the plebiscite it obviously must meet all normal tests of reasonableness and fairness.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the same minister.

May 13, 1992
Oral Questions
The minister will know that the Prime Minister and the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs have assured members of this House that there would be meaningful consultations. There have been no consultations with regard to the bill. There has been an information session concerning the contents of the bill and that was on Monday.
The minister makes reference to legal opinions. In the spirit of the so-called consultations and co-operation, will he not do the honourable thing and share those legal opinions with members of this House to ascertain whether or not the legal arguments are bogus arguments, as many members in this House speculate they are?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member's indignation is a little surprising since a week ago yesterday I discussed the measure with him. He offered no suggestions at that time. He was to discuss it with officials of his party, the chief of staff of the Leader of the Opposition on Monday. It was discussed with himself and the House leader of the New Democratic Party on Monday afternoon.
Again on Tuesday there were discussions with the House leaders and other people. At no time did the hon. member during those consultations and discussions suggest changes that could be made, except before this House in Question Period or afterwards to the media.
I remind the hon. member that we are talking about the integrity of the country. What is at issue is some details on how a plebiscite might be held if one is called. Let us not get so heated about these details, which we can work out together when the bill is brought forward, and put in jeopardy what we are all trying to save, this great country.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the government House leader.
If the government goes ahead with its referendum plan, we must ensure this exercise contributes to the country's unity and is not divisive. The government House leader will recall the following recommendation in the Beaudoin-Edwards committee's report that was
signed by his party, by the Liberals and by my own party, and I quote: "A referendum should require a national majority and a majority in each of the four regions".
My question for the government House leader is: How does the government intend to act on this recommendation, which was supported by his own party?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if we were proposing a referendum as a means of amending the Constitution of Canada, then of course some such formula like that or another formula which would be acceptable to the provinces of this country would have to be used.
What is being proposed is a mechanism for holding, if it is deemed desirable to do so, a non-binding plebiscite on the question of constitutional amendments. This will not supersede the constitutional requirement that any change receive the approval of seven provinces with 50 per cent of the population plus the House of Commons and the Senate. Therefore, any conditions as to what is a pass or failure for a plebiscite becomes irrelevant.
Those kinds of tests have to meet a political test in the sense of being seen as fair and so on. The result will obviously have some moral influence but will not have a legal influence. Therefore, the kinds of conditions the hon. leader of the New Democratic Party is talking about are really not applicable to this legislation.

Mr. Speaker, I am sure the House leader is not suggesting that the very well-respected member of his party, who was the cochair of the Edwards-Beaudoin committee, did not know that a referendum did not constitute a constitutional amendment. Of course he did and of course all the people in this House know that it requires the amending formula as set out in the Constitution, the approval of the provinces and 50 per cent of the population.
However, these are not picky details. If we are to believe that the government is sincere in seeking the opinions of Canadians, there must be some attitude on the part of the government that it is going to respect the opinions of Canadians. Therefore, I think it is very
May 13, 1992

Oral Questions
important that the government is able to give its rationale clearly for this referendum.
I would also like to raise the question of spending limits. The House leader said, in response earlier to a question, that when the committee met he would table the legal opinions.
I want to ask the House leader if he will table those legal opinions now about the possible challenges to spending limits under the charter of rights? Will he table them now so that we can all make an informed decision concerning the enabling legislation, not after the legislation comes to the House?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would remind the leader of the New Democratic Party that the Beaudoin-Edwards committee was looking at changes in the amending formula. It was not looking at whether a plebiscite as a means of consulting Canadians would be an appropriate mechanism or not.
Second, she ought not to jump to the conclusion that because enabling legislation for a plebiscite is being proposed that this automatically means it is going to occur. This, in a sense, is minutia compared to the main issues which are being discussed by the provinces and the federal government right now.
In terms of whether constraints on campaigning under umbrella committees, constraints on spending, are permissible given the charter of rights, we have a procedure in this House of first reading of a bill, which no one has really seen yet although they know the contents thereof, second reading during which we discuss the general principle, and then committee stage where we look at the kind of details the hon. member is concerned about.
I give again my assurance that should arguments be convincing that this legislation can be improved to make it appear more fair and to be more fair, then certainly we are open to them. At this time, I have no other responsibility but to accept the best legal advice given by the Department of Justice. The Department of Justice has the responsibility of advising the government on the applicability of the law in respect to proposals.
The hon. member should be patient. The bill will come forward and all members will have an opportunity to see it.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the House leader.
This government's definition of non-partisan seems to be: "We are the captain of the ship. You play by our rules. That is what we mean by non-partisan".
There is no rationale for not tabling the legal opinions this government has on limits to spending. There is absolutely no rationale unless this government wants to be partisan.
I want to give the House leader one more chance to be non-partisan. When it comes to formulating the question for a possible referendum, will the House leader give his commitment on behalf of the government that this will be a truly non-partisan committee made up of all members of this House, not only a government majority, that will help to formulate the question?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not know why the hon. leader of the New Democratic Party should get so accusatory in her comments. I had just said to her that I would be willing to accept improvements to the legislation once she sees it and sees its contents. Yet she comes back and responds that that is excessively partisan on my part.
I would suggest to the hon. member one of the things that makes it difficult to engage in consultations is that at the very time I was in discussion on this bill with the House leader of the New Democratic Party, her chief of staff was out briefing the press on all the details that had been given to her in private. That is what makes it difficult to proceed.
Shame.

Mr. Speaker, we in the Liberal Party are pleased that the leader of the New Democratic Party has changed her position on spending limits and now joins the Liberal Party in asking for spending limits. We think it is important.
I want to say there is no question that the people of Canada want to say yes to a new spirit of unity in this country as the government has proposed. The people of Canada want to say yes to a renewed country, but the people of Canada are clearly saying no to the old way of doing this. They want this House leader and this government to come clean today and give a commitment that contained within the referendum legislation that will be

May 13, 1992
Oral Questions
laid before the House of Commons on Friday will be provision for a fair and above board process, provision for spending limits.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there is a number of suppositions. First, the bill may be produced on Friday. I have not made that final decision yet.
Second, as I have indicated to his House leader, the question of spending limits and constraints on who may campaign, how much they spend and so on, is a difficult question to address because of the charter of rights.
As the hon. member properly said in his introductory remarks, what we are talking about here is the integrity of the country, the unity of the country. We are talking about a possible mechanism for including Canadians, consulting with Canadians on this important question.
I would ask the hon. member to have the patience of waiting until the bill is actually introduced in the House and we have a chance to look at it and use the usual procedures of this House, which are as fair as any democracy in the world.
I give the assurances I gave earlier, that changes which improve things and changes that are possible given the charter of rights will certainly be entertained.

Mr. Speaker, we on this side are very concerned about the attitude of the House leader. If the House leader truly believes that the charter prevents him from imposing spending limits on a referendum, it means that the House leader is preparing, one would suppose, if he is logical, to scrap the Canada Elections Act and the spending limits for general elections. We hope that is not the case.
I ask the House leader whether he will answer the question put by the Leader of the Opposition who asked this government what happens in the event of a referendum if any one of the regions of Canada says no. Will the government give an assurance today that the government would not proceed with constitutional change in the event that any region of Canada-the west, Ontario, Quebec or Atlantic Canada-said no? Can he give that assurance to the people of Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, no decision has been taken to hold the plebiscite. So to ask for assurance on how the results would be treated on something that has not been decided seems a little absurd. What is being proposed is the details of how one would hold a plebiscite if, and I underline the if, a decision were taken to hold one.
I think the hon. member is, might I say, a little premature in that question because no decision has been taken to hold a plebiscite or referendum.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs.
The minister and his department have repeatedly assured Canadians that prescription drug prices in Canada have increased at an annualized rate of 3.1 per cent. Yet a comprehensive report by Green Shield Services clearly states that the actual cost to consumers has been in excess of 11 per cent more per annum during that period of time.
These are the real facts. Why have the minister and his government been hiding them from Canadian consumers?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Dorothy Dobbie (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in fact the federal government is keeping the cost of the price of drugs down to about a 3.1 per cent average per year.
The hon. member knows very well that the Green Shield plan actually measures the increased costs of drugs on a different basis than the federal government's plan does. Therefore, the figures the government has and the Green Shield plan has are very similar to one another.

Mr. Speaker, my question then is for the Acting Prime Minister.
It is abundantly clear from this comprehensive report by Green Shield Services that Canadian consumers have been misled for the last four years on the real price increases for prescription drugs in Canada.
May 13, 1992

Will the Acting Prime Minister explain to Canadian consumers why they, senior citizens and provincial governments have been subject to the government using phoney figures for the last four years when it comes to real cost of prescription drugs in Canada?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Dorothy Dobbie (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, that is just utter nonsense. The government has not been using phoney figures and the hon. member knows that very well.
In fact the Green Shield plan study actually looks at changes in patterns of usage, the amount of dosages that prescriptions are prescribing, and so its figures differ. The government uses the unit cost per drug. That cost has risen on the average of about 3.1 per cent per year.
That is the fair and the most accurate way to measure these drug increases.

My question, Mr. Speaker, is for the government House leader. We did not have a full response to the question asked by the leader of my party.
In view of the fact that the Prime Minister and the minister in charge of the Constitution have many times talked about this being a non-partisan issue, I wonder if we could get a commitment today from the government House leader to make sure that when it comes to writing the question to be put to the Canadian people, if we get to that stage, there will be formed in this House a non-partisan committee of all the political parties of this House including the Reform Party of Canada so that we can make sure the question is non-partisan.
And the Bloc.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I say sincerely that I know the hon. member has as sincere an interest in the unity integrity of this country as anybody in the House. I give him this assurance, and he ought not to need it, because I am sure he would accept that the Prime Minister and the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs have at least as deep a commitment to the unity of this country as anybody else.
Oral Questions
On that basis he can rest assured that in fact we want all of those in this House who are committed to the unity of Canada to be a part of and contribute positively to whatever initiatives are brought forward, including possibly a referendum or plebiscite.
I want to say to the hon. member that my conversations with his House leader, the Liberal House leader, in private were all designed to try to have us work together in concert on this matter.
If in fact that is the desired way to proceed, I humbly suggest that some of the shots taken here in Question Period are not really conducive, nor do they provide much incentive to continue those kinds of conversations we have been having, which I think we ought to be able to have.

I cannot help but stress, Mr. Speaker, the importance of having a process at this stage that is not only fair but seen to be fair involving all members of Parliament.
My supplementary question goes back to the spending limits. I make it clear to the government House leader that our party is in favour of spending limitations so that we have a fair campaign.
In light of the fact that the Lortie commission on electoral reform in this country came out with a recommendation for very severe spending limits-and I assume it consulted legal advice before it made the recommendation-I wonder if the minister could now table his legal advice. The problem we have is if we do not have spending limits in the bill at first or second reading and we try to move spending limits during committee stage, it may be ruled out of order by the Speaker as being beyond the scope of the bill.
Could the minister now do that so we could have the benefit of the legal opinion and, if the spending limits are not there, put them in at this time?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am sure the hon. member will recognize that the Elections Act dealing with registered parties and penalties such as loss of seat and so on is quite a different question than a plebiscite, particularly a plebiscite in which provincial governments might in their own right participate on a yes or no side. I would ask him to reflect for a moment on what kind of restraints he would put on

May 13, 1992
Oral Questions
provincial governments and how they would be enforced, to give him one aspect of the problem.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources. The recent international agreement on climatic change sets no time or quantity limit for the signing parties. speakeroldname: Hon. Jean J. Charest (Minister of the Environment):
speechtext:

However, there is a commitment that will translate as a legal commitment for each country. There will be a reduction in greenhouse gases, with the exception of those covered by the Montreal Protocol. There is also a reference to reduction to the levels of previous years, including 1990. We feel, that this is a reflection, as the hon. member indicated, of the Canadian government's present policy as expressed in the green plan.

If the minister is to be taken seriously, will he call immediately a meeting of all major energy and environmental stakeholders in the country to develop the detailed action plan which is required if the government's commitment is to be taken seriously?

Small business is the engine of growth that we desperately need to get out of this recession. Yet this government has allowed desperately needed guaranteed loans to small business to plummet by 45 per cent, a drop of $660 million.
May 13, 1992

We have also brought in the small business financing program which will greatly help small business as well. That, together with having the lowest rate of corporate tax in the industrialized world should help.

speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the answer is quite simple. It is not necessary for aboriginal children to go to such schools. Wherever there are conditions of the sort that the hon. member has described, we will ensure that there are alternative arrangements provided.
The hon. member knows that there are a number of infrastructure improvements slated for the community of Red Sucker Lake. There are new sewer and water provisions and a new electrification program which I announced in Manitoba a couple of months ago. There is also a new school which will be constructed in the year 1994-1995.
In the meantime, the department has offered and done a complete inventory of necessary maintenance and improvement which should possibly be a solution for the interim period. speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: EXCISE TAX ACT AND INCOME TAX ACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to rise today to speak on behalf of the government on Bill C-75, an act to amend the Excise Tax Act and the Income Tax Act.
This bill amends the Excise Tax Act and the Income Tax Act to implement two key measures announced on December 6, 1991 to boost the transportation sector. These measures include a temporary loss offset program with a partial rebate of the federal excise tax on diesel and aviation fuel and an exemption from withholding tax for cross-border aircraft leases.
In addition to these two measures, the government also announced on December 6 changes to the capital costs allowance regulations which will increase the rate at which many transportation assets can be written off against taxable income.
As well, funding was announced for an institute for research in trucking issues and an owner-operators' trucking co-operative. I think all members will agree that a strong transportation sector is vital to all Canadians, to consumers and to businesses.
The measures contained in this bill and the other initiatives announced in December 1991 are the results of a review of the tax system as it applies to this sector to find ways to help the transportation sector cope with
Government Orders
short-term cash flow needs. They also represent a substantial commitment from the government to transportation. These measures complement the nearly $1 billion in benefits to the transportation sector resulting from the replacement of the inefficient manufacturers' sales tax with the GST.
I would like to take a few minutes to outline the excise tax transportation rebate loss offset program. The excise tax transportation rebate is designed to provide an immediate benefit to firms in the transportation sector with significant cash flow needs. The federal excise tax rate on diesel and aviation fuel is currently 4 cents per litre. This bill will implement an excise tax rebate of 3 cents per litre on diesel and aviation fuel purchased in 1991-1992.
Transportation businesses that use fuel subject to the 4-cent per litre federal excise tax are eligible for the tax rebate. However businesses which are exempt from income tax will not be eligible.
Businesses that elect to receive this rebate will be required to reduce their income tax losses by $10 for every $1 of rebate received. This feature will effectively target the benefits of the program to firms most in need.
Loss carry forwards would normally be used to reduce taxable income in future years when a firm becomes profitable. Firms that receive the rebate must cash in these losses. The rebate thus provides an immediate cash flow benefit at the cost of lower loss carry forwards to offset income taxes as conditions improve.
The reduction in loss carry forwards means they will be paying income taxes sooner than if they did not claim the rebate. Businesses will be able to file claims for fuel purchased or imported in 1991 as soon as this bill receives Royal Assent. The administrative mechanisms are in place to ensure that the rebates will be paid quickly to eligible claimants.
Claims for rebates for fuel purchased or imported in 1992 must be filed during the first six months of next year. No rebate will be payable on fuel which is exempt from the excise tax or where a refund or other rebate is payable.
For example, aviation fuel used on international flights and marine diesel used for voyages through international waters are exempt from excise tax and so will not be eligible for this rebate.

Government Orders
In order to make it easier for independent owner-operators to access this program, this bill provides an alternative rebate which trucking businesses may elect to claim in place of the standard rebate. Under this simpler option a rebate of 1.5 cents per litre on excisable fuel may be claimed up to a maximum of $500 annually. It will be significantly simpler as no assessment of the business's current or future income tax liability will be required.
This excise tax transportation rebate will give Canadian transportation businesses an important short-term boost of about $120 million in each of the two years. This will help to ensure we maintain the vibrant transportation sector essential for Canada's economic well-being. The bill will also enact the government's proposal to exempt from non-resident withholding tax all payments on cross-border aircraft leases negotiated on an arm's length basis. This exemption will apply to all lease payments made after the announcement date, December 6, 1991, for leases entered into after 1990.
The non-resident withholding tax is a tax imposed on most cross-border payments such as interest, rent, royalties, dividends and payments for businesses and services. The statutory rate is 25 per cent but this is often reduced in bilateral treaties to 10 per cent or 15 per cent.
Currently the government provides an exemption for aircraft leases where the aircraft is used outside Canada. The industry has told us it is difficult to comply with this and that it has imposed operational constraints on Canada's airlines. Extending the exemption to all aircraft will simplify the provision and also enable Canadian carriers to access offshore leasing markets to finance new acquisitions.
This withholding tax exemption will cost the Canadian treasury about $15 million a year. The benefits to Canadian carriers on the other hand will be much greater because the current rules limit the ability of Canadian airlines to access foreign leasing markets.
In closing, this government recognizes that the transportation sector is an important part of the basic infrastructure of Canada. These two measures will give a timely boost to that sector and with the measures introduced in the budget will provide stimulus to the
economy while maintaining the government's commitment to sound fiscal management.
In recognizing the importance of these measures to the transportation sector and to the Canadian economy as a whole, I urge all hon. members to give their full support to this bill and to ensure that it is approved by this House as soon as possible.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am glad to hear the words of the member on the government side pledging support for Canada's transportation sector.
Part of this bill is directed at legislating some of the changes that were announced last December by the government with respect to what really amounts to nothing short of a crisis in Canada's trucking industry.
You will recall, Madam Speaker, that last year we had for a period of time a vast array of rigs outside the parliamentary precincts on Wellington Street here in Ottawa as truckers from all over came here to express not only their grievances but their concern that they were being put in a position where they were going to lose their businesses and their vehicles, all as a result of their inability to be truly competitive with truckers in the United States.
The response contained in Bill C-75 is appreciated. This party supports it but it falls well short of what could have been done and what should have been done on behalf of the trucking industry.
May 13, 1992

I am going to take a few minutes to revisit many of the suggestions that my colleague from York West brought forward on this issue last year and which provided the government an opportunity to begin to take some action.
He suggested, for example, that a shorter period of depreciation of equipment be permitted. This is addressed in part in the announcement that the minister made last December but even then it fell well short of what is needed. While the trucking industry indicated a need to more rapidly depreciate equipment that is very expensive and which they had acquired, the minister's response was to allow depreciation to be accelerated with respect to purchases of tractors and trucks after December 1991. He did not touch the question of trailers or the rate of depreciation of existing equipment that was already owned by many of these small businesses, in particular those that were already in financial difficulty.
My colleague called upon the government to provide relief on its tax on diesel fuel. As the member opposite outlined, there is some such relief in Bill C-75. From what I can understand and in discussions that I have had, virtually nobody in the trucking business is going to be taking advantage of the rebate on diesel fuel because it entails a 1 to 10 loss of the loss-carry-forward provisions under the Income Tax Act.
I realize that is very technical, but essentially the point is this: In the trucking industry, as in all businesses, we enable, under the tax system in Canada, businesses to carry forward business losses for a period of up to seven years. If a loss is incurred this year and profit is earned next year, we allow the profit next year to be reduced by this year's losses so as to spread out the tax burden a little bit more fairly, rather than rigidly limiting it to one year at a time. That is one of the reasons, as it happens, that occasionally businesses that are profitable do not pay any tax, because they may be profitable this year, but they may have experienced losses the previous year.
What the government has done is to require these trucking businesses to give up $10 of loss-carry-forward for every $1 of fuel tax rebate that they claim. In effect, with roughly a 44 per cent or 50 per cent corporate tax over all, including federal and provincial taxes, the loss-carry-forward that is lost to the trucker is much greater than the value of the rebate if they return to profitability in a short period of time. It really would only
Government Orders
be effective for companies that are holding losses from five, six or seven years earlier which would otherwise expire.
In point of fact, although the government has tried to make this sound like it is a generous provision, it is really of little, if any, use. It provides for a 1.5 cent rebate up to $500 for small trucking companies. Anything helps, but Canadians will be interested to know that for a large rig that may be about 1.5 to 1.75 of a tank of fuel. That is how much the government is helping out in this circumstance.
My colleague from York West suggested that something be done with respect to the GST in order to help the truckers. The member opposite who spoke on this bill praised the GST as being an assistance to this industry.
Our suggestion was that the remittance cycle for truckers be extended a little bit, from 45 to 70 days, and that the time taken to provide GST rebates to truckers be reduced. This would help the cash flow situation that these operators are in. Again there is no response from the government. Again the truckers are left on their own to try to deal with the problems they have.
We suggested that there be permission for tax deductibility of the cost of an operating licence from income. This is an historic complaint. In 1987 when deregulation of trucking was brought in, trucking companies in Canada had as much as $200 million in the value of trucking licences that had been previously issued. These licences maintained value and could be bought and sold in the marketplace. With deregulation, the asset value of a licence was immediately reduced to zero.
When deregulation came in, it spawned the possibility of much more competition but without any kind of adjustment period for existing companies to take into account the increased competition, together with the loss of an asset, which in many cases was quite valuable.
It is interesting to compare the approach our government took to that which was taken in the United States, where in similar circumstances trucking companies were able to write off the existing cost of their licences over a two-year period. That gave them an opportunity to make the adjustments that were necessary by sheltering some income in those two years and to make certain adjust-

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
merits so they could be as competitive as the new competition on the roads.
There is a lesson here for the farming communities across Canada. We know very well that behind closed doors the government opposite is negotiating the elimination of our marketing board system and expects to replace it with a system of tariffication. Farmers who have paid a lot of money for their quotas ought to be looking at what the government did in trucking and thinking about what is going to happen to the value of their quotas when the system of supply management is abandoned.
If the trucking example holds, it would appear that what is going to happen is nothing. The value of the quota will be reduced to zero overnight and the farmers will be entitled to continue the existing system of depreciation which is of very minor assistance to them. Beware. That is what happened to the truckers and we see no assistance whatsoever in this bill.
We suggested last year that efforts be made to improve the federal-provincial co-ordination on policy matters affecting the transportation sector. We have seen no movement on that issue whatsoever.
We asked for improved enforcement and increased penalties for those engaged in illegal cabotage in Canada. There has been no movement on that.
We urged the federal government to increase its investment in road infrastructure. This is a very important matter because in talking about these rebates for excise taxes on diesel fuel and so on, we have a very significant source of revenue for the Government of Canada, which it takes directly out of this industry. It is approximately $5 billion in revenue for the Government of Canada.
One would think that when that much money is being sucked out of the system, the federal government would be looking for ways to reapply those revenues to make it a better system for the trucks to use. One would think it would be going into road infrastructure. Do members know how much is going back in? About 5 per cent.
While there is a major burden on our industry which is endeavouring to compete with the United States, a
major burden reducing our competitiveness, in return the federal government offers a pittance, a 5 per cent pittance to the cost of the infrastructure that is essential to this business.
We will support the bill and we will not endeavour to delay it in any way. It is with a great deal of disappointment that we note that the government's response to what is really nothing short of a crisis in this important sector of our economy is so poor and so inadequate.

speechtext: Madam Speaker, at the outset I would like to indicate that I am going to be splitting the time available to the New Democratic Party with my colleague, the member for Essex-Windsor, 50/50. Therefore I will rely on you to tell me when it is time to wind up.

subtopic: EXCISE TAX ACT AND INCOME TAX ACT
speechtext: Time is up.

subtopic: EXCISE TAX ACT AND INCOME TAX ACT
speechtext:
Don't you all wish.
I want to begin back before this time last year when not just in Toronto, which has had years of experience with truckers circulating around the legislature since at least before 1975, not just in Windsor where the truckers blockaded the bridge to the United States, but here where, I think for one of the first times, the Elouse of Commons experienced the sheer power of the transport trucks parked on Wellington Street for days on end. They made it very clear to this House and to Canadians that the trucking industry was in jeopardy.
I want to begin before that time, because I want to talk about the underlying causes of what we saw on our roads, our bridges and our streets last year. The problem began with a decision taken by the Government of Canada to deregulate trucking, and then a decision by the then Liberal government of the province of Ontario to follow suit and deregulate trucking in that province.
That decision created great expectations. There were a whole bunch of independent-minded individuals who said: "Great, now I can get a rig. Now, I can go into business and earn my living by carrying produce. I do not have to go through a complicated and expensive regulatory procedure. I do not have to prove that there is a need for my services. I just have to convince a bank manager that I am a good financial risk. I just have to go out and get insurance and then I am in business".
May 13, 1992

A lot of people did that. In fact, so many people did it that it very quickly became obvious that there were more trucks than there were cargoes to carry.
Under regulation there was a balance. I admit that the Ontario Highway Transport Board in its regulation setting and decision making was flawed, there was some over-protection. However, by throwing out the total system we raised expectations that were possible to fill in the short term but impossible to sustain in the long term.
Add to that the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. Add to that the recession. Add to that the inevitable consolidation of the trucking companies, again as a direct result of deregulation both in Canada and the United States. Also add to that the reality that as a country that has one-tenth the population it is physically impossible for us to create a megatrucking company that could compete on a level playing field with an American carrier.
Add to that mix our taxation laws, whether fuel taxes, write-offs, investment or what have you. Then mix in the difference in labour laws and safety laws and our geography, which is a ribbon along the Canada-U.S. border with most of our commerce being east-west. Our neighbours to the south have a fully integrated grid system.
Mix that all together and we had the makings of a disaster for the trucking industry. What we saw a year ago outside this Chamber, in Toronto, in Windsor, in Cornwall, in British Columbia and elsewhere was a cry from the truckers saying: "Help, we are in trouble. We cannot make ends meet. We are being outdone by our American competitors. They are fuelling up south of the river and taking their cargo to Montreal and Toronto with still enough gas to get back to the border".
Although, we also heard some stories about the bus only making it to the top of the bridge and somebody then having to come across with a jerrycan to fill it up to get it over the hump back down to the United States where it could fill up with extremely cheap gasoline, most of it coming from Canada. There was an advantage in doing so in terms of over-all costs.
They cried out for help and this government responded with peanuts. In fact, someone suggested that they were invisible peanuts, or peanuts painted with
Government Orders
invisible ink, because they are here today and gone tomorrow.
First, it is only for two years. Second, you may take the $500 through your reduction in the excise tax of 3 cents a litre, or the 1.5 cents a litre, but you have to pay it back later.
It is a short-term tank and a half of gas or fuel oil that really is not going to deal with the underlying problems affecting the trucking industry, which is too many truckers, too little cargo and too much effective competition from south of the border.
A week ago today I was in Quebec City where I sat in on the third annual North American conference on road transportation. Truckers and trucking companies from Mexico, the United States and Canada came together to talk about their future. While they voiced optimism about their ability to compete, as I sat there listening I said that I had heard this line before.
I heard it from Max Ward, who used to be the owner of Wardair, which is now part of Canadian; I heard it from the gentleman who was the owner of City Express, now gone. They were pumping up their chests about how great deregulation was going to be and how they could beat the big boys.
However, they did not. The reality of the situation of the system in Canada and the U.S. today is that it is bad news for Canadians and better news for the Americans.
As I sat there I began to understand that what the government has done to try and address the problem is minuscule. It really does not deal with those problems. For example, it does not deal, nor does the North American free trade agreement, with the fact that when a Canadian carrier takes a load from Toronto to Milwaukee the Canadian carrier can pick up another cargo in Milwaukee and bring it back to Canada, but it cannot relocate. It has to pick it up from the same terminal.
However, Canada in its usual generosity has said to American carriers that it thinks it logical that the carriers should be able to reposition themselves so that when they bring a load into Windsor it is okay to pick up more goods in Windsor and take them to Toronto where they can pick up their other load to go back to the United States.

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
Once again rather than trying to hammer out a deal at the bargaining table, whether it is a sectoral agreement or it is in the North American free trade agreement, Canada has given up things before it had to, it has given benefits to Americans that are not reciprocated. They are not reciprocating in the United States so we do not get the same advantage.
We must realistically deal with the problem before our trucking industry. We must develop adjustment programs that will allow truckers to get out of the business and move on to something else with a more stable future. We must downsize the industry to ensure that there is a better balance between supply and demand.
We must also make sure-and I regret that we have to go to this point-to eliminate any of the competitive disadvantages that Canadian carriers find themselves in, whether it is taxation, write-offs or whatever.
Elowever, on the safety side we have to negotiate to ensure that the American truckers match if not better whatever standards we have in Canada, whether they concern safety, labour, hours of work, or whatever. That is also very clear.
I know that my time is up. I appreciate the opportunity to address this bill. We will be supporting it at second reading. We look forward to a reasonably short review in committee because it is important, despite how miserly the government has been, to give the truckers at least the option of tapping into this particular assistance as soon as possible.

Madam Speaker, I appreciate the member's intervention.

subtopic: EXCISE TAX ACT AND INCOME TAX ACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this is a case in which the trucking industry across this country has put forward in many different ways-sometimes in the form of direct protest, sometimes in the form of position papers, sometimes in the form of discussions with ministers at both the federal and the provincial levels-its very deep concerns about what is happening to it as an industry and what as a consequence is happening to thousands of truckers across this country.
May 13, 1992

In my constituency literally dozens of companies have had to shut down or they have had to reduce their operation sharply because of their inability to cope with the deregulated situation established through government legislation by this present federal government.
We have in front of us at the moment a bill which offers some relief. I do not want to suggest that it does not offer any relief. It does. The point is and the point which my colleague made quite effectively I thought is that the amount offered is extremely limited.
The member for South Shore suggested that in fact what we were talking about was $120 million over two years and this was something that should be taken quite seriously. What he fails to recognize is that parts of the legislation indicate that that improvement in cash flow for trucking companies, for truckers, which will come out of this legislation because of the three cent per litre rebate which will be provided, will be paid back by these truckers in the future through their inability to deduct as much as they otherwise would have been able to from their expenses.
The consequences in fact for the treasury of this country are very much less than $120 million. Exactly how much less, it is going to be difficult to be sure of until we see how the whole thing works out over the years.
For the existing companies, those companies which take up this benefit will be required to reduce their income tax losses which they could write off by $10 for every $1 which is rebated to them as part of this three cent per litre rebate.
That tells me that if companies continue to absorb significant losses, and that certainly looks to be the case because there is nothing fundamental which has been done to deal with the problems of the trucking industry in this legislation or in any of the measures which the government has taken, it is quite likely that in the years ahead every single penny of these rebates will be paid back by trucking companies and independent owner-operators which are continuing to suffer losses and cannot deduct those losses at their full value, but instead must deduct them at significantly less value.
Government Orders
What we have here is a very minuscule response to a very considerable problem in this country. It is a considerable problem which we in Windsor especially have felt the brunt of. It has not just been a case of our truckers who have lost their jobs, but the frustration which these truckers have felt. There have been continual blockades which have taken place on the Ambassador Bridge between Windsor and the United States which certainly has brought home to this government the need to take some action. That I am willing to recognize.
It has also brought considerable economic loss and chaos in many cases to the economy of my city. Windsor and Essex County have suffered considerably in terms of lost economic benefits from the blockades which have taken place. We have considerable concern not just for truckers, but for the future of our community's economic base, that what the government does is something which sufficiently responds to the problems of truckers across this country.
As I look at the original demands which truckers made, there is no way that one can suggest that those small items which the government has put before us today respond to the concerns which truckers put forward when these protests first began.
If we go back to the first protest for instance, and I am quoting here from some of the demands put forward by Canadian truckers fighting back, they talked about the reduction in the fuel taxes. There has been a response to that. They also talked about a five year tax exemption on new and used equipment for the trucking industry. They talked about exemption from the GST. They talked about seeing to it that there was an attempt to hit foreign truckers coming into this country, especially American truckers, in a way that those truckers had to pay the excise tax on fuel which Canadian truckers have to pay. They asked for lower insurance rates for the trucking industry. Most important, they asked for stepped up monitoring and enforcement of regulations. They suggested that the cabotage laws, those laws which make it illegal for trucking companies from the United States that have shipped a load to Montreal, let us say, to pick up a load in Montreal and bring it back to a Canadian destination such as Windsor. They asked for strict enforcement of the laws against that.

Government Orders
I have seen and have held in my very hand examples of bills of lading of foreign trucks which were loaded in Montreal, owned in the United States and driven by American drivers, brought back to Windsor and unloaded at destinations in Windsor.

speechtext: It is called deregulation.

speechtext:
In fact this is something that even under the government's deregulation is illegal, yet because the federal government has not been prepared to permit the provincial governments to enforce these laws against cabotage, this kind of illegal activity that I have been describing, truckers in Canada have found themselves continually out-competed by this kind of illegal action on the part of American truckers.
It is not just a question of illegal action either. The regulation which we need in this country if we are going to see a future that will be at all bright for our truckers is regulation which re-establishes some control over the number of interprovincial licences that are issued. This is not something that the government has not heard about.
I quote here from a letter from the Minister of Transport of the province of Ontario written last May in which the Minister of Transport in Ontario said: "I feel it is also of vital importance that you give some indication and support for the plight of the truckers by announcing measures similar to those taken by Ontario. In particular, an announcement of a moratorium on interprovincial and trans-border trucking licences should be made immediately to arrest the precipitous decline of the Canadian trucking industry".
That has not taken place. Instead what we have had are a puny set of tax measures, a puny set of changes in capital depreciation possibilities and a puny set of grants to set up a co-op purchasing system for independent owner-operators. All of these are good moves.
My final comment is: Why could the government not have listened to truckers and taken not just these tiny, baby steps but some significant action to put the trucking industry in Canada on a fair competitive basis against the United States?
