speakeroldname: Hon. Shirley Martin (for the Minister of Finance) moved
speechtext: that Bill C-74, an act to amend the Customs Act, the Customs Tariff and the Excise Tax Act, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Economics envelope.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased on behalf of the government to introduce debate on Bill C-74, an act to amend the Customs Act, the Customs Tariff and the Excise Tax Act.
Bill C-74 seeks to amend legislation administered by Revenue Canada, Customs and Excise, relating to the introduction of penalty and interest provisions, and to postal and courier provisions in the Customs Act, the Customs Tariff and the Excise Tax Act.
Government Orders
These are important measures and require a number of amendments, many of them of a very technical nature.
I intend to deal with the penalty and interest provisions first, then pass on to the courier and postal issues.
Revenue Canada, Customs and Excise has been involved with several significant initiatives during the last few years designed to streamline operations, to ensure the integrity of program delivery, to improve service to client groups and to enhance revenue collection capability.
The purpose of the proposed amendments relating to the penalty and revised interest provisions is threefold: first, to correct imbalances in the current interest provisions of customs legislation and to introduce penalties for the lack of compliance in certain instances; second, it is to enhance voluntary compliance by providing an incentive for the provision of timely and accurate information to customs; and third, it is to help create a level playing field for Canadian importers and Canadian businesses.
For the vast numbers of importers who voluntarily comply with customs requirements, the proposed amendments will have no impact on day-to-day operations. Rather, these measures are aimed at those commercial importers who find it financially rewarding to delay filing their accounting documents or paying their fair share of duties and taxes.
I would like to assure this House that these measures are not designed to affect the travelling public. The legal provisions for paying interest to importers to whom Revenue Canada owes money are much different from the provisions that apply to money which is owed to the department by importers.
This imbalance has resulted in a decided disincentive for importers to declare the correct origin, classification and value of their importations. The result is that duties are unpaid. It has also provided an incentive for customs clientele to delay paying amounts owing, thereby providing themselves with free working capital at the expense of both the Crown and those importers who do comply.
The current interest provisions are being revised in order to remove the incentive not to comply and to bring them more into line with normal commercial practices.

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
The root of the problem lies in the current legislation. For example, if an importer pays excess duty a refund is given of the excess plus interest from the day after the duty was originally paid to the date of the refund cheque.
If an importer, however, underpays duty by not declaring the correct amount payable at the time of importation, and the underpayment is corrected by either the importer voluntarily amending the entry or by customs detecting and correcting the incorrect declaration, the importer pays no interest whatever on the duty which should have been paid in the first place.
Current rules allow importers five days from the date of release to file accounting documents for the goods and pay the duty and tax at the end of the month. There is no provision which permits customs to charge interest if the importer does not pay on the due date.
The recent move to monthly payment of accounts presents an even greater incentive to late file accounting documents, especially for large shipments imported close to the end of the month cycle. By postponing accounting past the 24th of the month, the importer would gain one month of interest-free use of the duties and taxes due unless the legislation is changed.
The proposed amendments contained in this bill are designed to ensure that the importing community meets its obligation to pay duties and taxes in a timely way.
In sum, the bill will provide for the application of interest and penalty charges in the case of late accounting for goods, the late payment of duties and taxes, and in the case of subsequent assessments and reassessments. Their application will be tempered by the ability of the Minister of National Revenue to waive them and to extend time frames for payment.
We are also taking the opportunity to bring the interest provisions into line with commercial practices by charging and refunding interest on a compounded daily basis.
I want to emphasize again that the proposals will have no negative impact on the vast majority of importers who file documents and pay duties and taxes within the prescribed time periods. Moreover, when importers have legitimate reasons for being late, allowances will be made.
What we are trying to ensure is that deliberate or chronic late payers are not rewarded by having what are in effect interest-free loans at taxpayers' expense. The legislation would remedy the problem.
I would now like to turn your attention to the second part of my comments on Bill C-74, those dealing with the importing of parcels through the mail.
The proposed legislation would modify policies which encourage significant Canadian shopping through foreign mail order houses. It would also change a system which encourages Canadian mail order houses to establish direct marketing operations outside Canada to sell back into the country. This has resulted in a significant loss of federal revenue and is a subsidy to those who use the mails to import goods.
The proposed changes would help level the playing field between Canadian retailers and foreign mail order firms by ensuring reasonably equitable duty and tax treatment. They would also ensure any changes to achieve equity are done in a fiscally responsible manner.
The current postal imports remission order, the courier imports remission order and the GST legislation allow parcels valued at $40 or less to be imported without duty and tax. There has been growing criticism in recent years that these exemptions and their administration, in particular on the postal side, are having negative effects on Canadian businesses.
The government has heard from many people asking for changes to the existing system. Representations were received from the Retail Council and the Canadian Direct Marketing Association, independent retailers and other Canadian small business people and by members of this House.
The mail order firms we heard from are located not only in large metropolitan centres such as Vancouver, Calgary, Ottawa, Toronto and Montreal, but also in small communities such as Viking, Alberta, Goodwood and Pakenham, Ontario, Aylmer, Quebec, and Clarenville, Newfoundland.
There has been an increasing number of Canadian purchases from foreign mail order distributors. Customs has experienced a 46 per cent increase in the volume of dutiable and taxable parcels over the last two years and it estimates that in 1990 Canadian purchases from foreign mail order houses exceeded $900 million.
May 13, 1992

Sales into Canada are expected to grow as foreign mail order houses target the Canadian market with aggressive catalogue distribution and media advertising campaigns. Foreign mail order firms have recently begun to market their products in Canada in substantial numbers, particularly since 1988, through the distribution of catalogues. Others are expected to follow their lead upon completion of test marketing currently underway.
This is an important issue affecting an important sector of the Canadian economy, the Canadian direct marketing industry which represents a total annual sales volume of $7.8 billion. Of that amount, there are approximately 600 firms and an estimated 35,620 people employed in catalogue direct marketing with an estimated $2.2 billion in sales volume.
A study commissioned by the Canadian Direct Marketing Association concluded that the postal and courier exemptions have had a severe impact on the Canadian industry and created a competitive disadvantage for Canadian catalogue firms in the under $40 price market. It is estimated that Canadian catalogue firms lost $260 million in sales in 1990 and that approximately 4,170 jobs have been lost since 1986. The current exemption levels are considered to have played a significant role in these losses. By 1995 the total industry loss is projected to be 7,430 jobs and annual sales of $469 million.
In terms of annual industry sales growth in Canada, it is estimated that between 1977 and 1985 these were healthy at 7 per cent. Since 1986, these have stagnated at a compounded annual rate of 3.2 per cent. Comparable U.S. growth was 8.3 per cent from 1977 to 1985 and 12.4 per cent from 1985 to 1990.
Why the difference in growth rates? Hon. members will be interested in some of the statistics that provide part of the answer.
An Ontario based firm selling a Canadian-made article for a $40 catalogue price would deliver it to a customer in Canada for $50.26 including GST, provincial sales taxes, shipping and handling. However, the same company could ship the Canadian-made good to the U.S. and deliver it to the same customer in Ontario for $45.36 with the same dollar value of profit margin and after allowing for differences in postal rates.
Government Orders
In an industry where net profit margins typically run on the order of 7 per cent to 8 per cent of sales, this 10 per cent difference is clearly critical and can be directly attributed to the exemptions levels.
Therefore, you can see how the duty and tax exemptions for parcels valued at $40 or less creates a serious competitive inequity for Canadian retailers in competing for Canadian mail order business.
Canadian retailers must charge GST and a provincial sales tax on their sales when mailed to customers within the province as well as pay duty on their imports. However, mail imports valued at $40 or less are not subject to the GST or duty and the federal government does not collect provincial tax except when it is harmonized with the GST on goods.
For all the above reasons, we have proposed legislation that would lead to the implementation of the following changes on July 1, 1992:
The exemptions which allow duty and tax-free entry of postal or courier imports valued at $40 or less would be reduced to $20.
Revenue Canada, Customs and Excise, would engage Canada Post to perform specific functions currently performed by Customs. Such services would include the collection of duty, provincial sales tax where harmonized, and the GST.
Canada Post would charge a $5 fee for the handling and collection services. This is in line with the government's effort to help recover costs where appropriate from those who benefit from the service. The fee is similar to that charged by other countries.
Canada Post would also bear the cost of clearing priority courier items through customs as is done by private couriers. The proposed legislation also provides for the voluntary registration of foreign mail order firms for the collection of GST and duties.
Non-resident mail order houses would be given the option of collecting and remitting applicable duties and taxes, that is, the GST and any provincial sales taxes harmonized with the GST, on all shipments over the $20 exemption limit sent to Canadian destinations.
Postal shipments on which duty and GST have been pre-collected will not be subject to the $5 handling fee since all costs associated with the assessment, collection,

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
and remittance of these duties and taxes will be absorbed by the foreign suppliers.
Providing foreign mail order houses with the option of pre-collecting duty and tax on their shipments to Canada is important as it would reduce the number of dutiable and taxable parcels to be processed by Customs and Canada Post. A number of foreign firms have already expressed an interest in pursuing this option.
As a complement to the exemption on postal and courier imports the customs tariff also provides for the importation of gifts duty and tax-free if they are valued under $40 with duty and taxes payable only on the amount over the exemption level.
Under the proposed legislation the gift exemption which allows duty and tax-free entry for gifts sent to Canadians through the mail or imported personally by non-residents would be increased from $40 to $60 bringing us into line with other countries. This is in response to numerous recent representations from individual Canadians across the country. The gift exemption is intended to deal with unsolicited gifts for family and friends abroad. These goods do not compete against goods sold in Canada. There has been much criticism regarding the level of exemption on gifts because it is lower than those of other countries.
The review of the exemptions for postal and courier imports provided an opportunity to reassess our policy on gifts and to consider the merits of amending the exemption levels to make them more liberal.
I want to conclude by saying that the proposed legislation is not a panacea for the complex issue of cross-border shopping through the mail. Moreover I do not expect that all Canadians will be happy with it. However it proposes measures that are equitable and a good start on the road to ensuring that Canadian mail order firms can compete with foreign competitors in Canada.
In addition, the initiative before us also proposes effective remedies to imbalances in existing import penalties and interest provisions. The bill moves Canadians in the direction of a fairer and a more just system of doing business and I commend it to all members.
There have been consultations and I think you will find, Madam Speaker, there is unanimous consent for the following motion:
That the motion for the second reading of Bill C-74, an act to
amend the Customs Act, the Customs Thrift, and the Excise Thx Act
be amended by having the bill referred to the Standing Committee
on Finance rather than the legislative committee.

Agreed.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is my pleasure to speak on this bill on behalf of my colleagues in the Liberal Party.
A number of the amendments we are talking about this afternoon are indeed technical in nature, as the member for South Shore indicated earlier this afternoon. Nevertheless that is not universally the case.
I want to speak briefly on schedule 7 of the tax act which is amended to provide for the lowering of the exemption for the importation of products through the mail.
The member, when reading his prepared notes, indicated to all of us this was something that members had made representations about for some time. That is quite true and people in the industry wanted a change.
What he did not say is that it is his own government which raised the exemption to start with and the only reason it has to be lowered is because the government raised it for reasons that no one of this side of the House can understand.
I certainly did not ask for that exemption to be increased, my colleagues did not ask for it, and certainly the Canadian retailing industry never wanted that exemption to be increased at all. The government increased that exemption to $40 and is now lowering it back to $20; in a sense admitting, although belatedly, that it made a mistake to start with.
I want to express what this has done in the constituency of Glengarry-Prescott-Russell and elsewhere. In my riding there are Canadian mail order houses and many Canadian retail operations. Retailers and mail order houses in my riding were stuck. In each case they
May 13, 1992

Government Orders
were competing against American companies which were exempt from those very things we were asking Canadian businesses to pay.
For example, the exemption was supposed to be for $40 purchases. If you are a U.S. mail order house what do you do if someone in Canada buys three or four items, the total value of which is $99? You send them in three or four little boxes. What do you achieve? You are below the $40 maximum for each individual box being shipped. Therefore no duty, no GST, no provincial sales tax was paid.

Madam Speaker, is a retailer in my constituency or yours exempted from collecting customs duty or GST or provincial sales tax, if the item is worth less than $40? Of course not. All retailers are obliged to collect these taxes from everyone, to the last cent; five cents here, four cents there, $10 here, $50 on another item, and so forth.
There is no exemption of any kind for businesses in our constituencies. However, big American companies like L.L. Bean can ship merchandise to Canada without being subject to the same regulations Canadian retailers must comply with today.

This issue was raised in the House a long time ago. [Translation]
On May 30, 1990 I raised this matter in a speech in the House of Commons, and I may refer you, Madam Speaker, to Hansard at page 12063. At the time, I had a question for the Minister of National Revenue, the same minister we still have today. Madam Speaker, I see from my notes that you were in the chair. I am sure you will remember I told the minister that a company in my riding, McIntyre and Dodd Marketing which operates from its head office in Rexdale but has a distribution centre in Hawkesbury, Ontario, and another one in Laval, Quebec, ships merchandise across Canada.
In his letter to me, dated May 22, 1990, the president of the company, Mr. John Dragan, said the following:

I would like to draw your attention to a loophole in our laws that an American company is making use of that if it continues may force us to close our Hawkesbury plant. Our plant in peak periods last year employed 165 people.
As you may be aware, the Canadian government, a few years ago changed the dollar value amount on parcels that enter Canada from the United States through the postal system to be duty-free if the value is $35 or less.
Actually I think the amount was $40. In any case I will continue:
The U.S. company in question, Direct Marketing Enterprises out of Westbuiy, New York, is using Canadian media to promote its mail order products with a return address in Windsor, Ontario.
This scheme was quite clever. The U.S. mail order company would rent a postal box in Windsor. If Canadians wanted to shop from this mail order house they certainly felt they were buying in Canada because this U.S. company had rented a postal box in Canada. What about the conscience of Canadian consumers? It was of no concern because they thought, mistakenly of course, that they were buying from a Canadian company.
I will continue with the text of the letter:
The orders are dispatched to a fulfilment operation in Detroit where the orders are processed -to the border ready to be mailed at the closest Canada Post parcel centre. The average value of each parcel is under $35 therefore allowing the goods to be duty-free.
We see how it works. A U.S. company advertises in Canada, rents a postal box in Canada, gets the orders sent there, goes to the Canadian postal box, picks up all its orders, carries them physically or electronically across the border to the United States, and then ships its merchandise back into Canada using the Canadian postal system. In so doing it totally circumvents the goods and services tax, any custom duties that are due on the parcels, as well as the provincial sales tax. Is that fair? Of course not.
I raised this issue in the House of Commons, as I indicated previously, on May 30, 1990. Here is what the Minister of National Revenue said at that time.
"Madam Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to answer briefly the concerns of my hon. friend".

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
This was, of course, in answer to my question.
"As he pointed out in his comments, it is true that I am very much aware of this growing problem. I say growing because this law has been in place for many years."
That is not entirely accurate, but in any case he continued:
"It is apparent that there are some organizations south of the border that are starting to abuse what was initially a good law to benefit families and other non-commercial uses, as the member pointed out. I have already met on at least two occasion, and perhaps more, with individual business people who have outlined exactly the same concern, the latest of which was just a couple of weeks ago. At that time I told them, and I give my hon. friend the same commitment, that I would begin discussions immediately not only with my officials but with officials with the Department of Finance to see how we could rectify the situation".
The minister agreed to take appropriate steps to correct the situation, and that was on May 30, 1990. Today, May 13, 1992, we are finally considering this bill, not to get rid of the problem but to lessen the impact somewhat.

The problem is still going to be there, although of course this bill will make things somewhat better. Will this bill stop L. L. Bean of the United States from sending shirts into Canada at $19 each using the postal system and using a separate padded envelope for each shirt? Obviously not.
I say that what the government is trying to do is in the right direction in this regard but it does not go far enough. It should have made that exception for only those things that are of nominal value. If someone walks across the border with an ice-cream cone or something, we do not charge the tax on it. I am willing to accept that.
I am willing to accept some nominal provision where it is not worth the trouble of collecting a tax and, even if we did collect it, it would not have any deterring value.
Unless it meets those two tests, the exemption should not be there. The $20 exemption that is there will still enable companies to ship goods in three or four different bags into Canada. It will still enable them to circumvent our laws. That $20 should have been perhaps $4 or $5 or some ridiculous small amount to stop that nonsense.
I am not against U.S. mail order houses if they want to sell into Canada. So be it, but they should not be exempt from our laws. I have to pay tax. You have to pay tax, Madam Speaker.
I have to pay tax.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
The member for Kingston and the Islands pays tax and everyone else. The store owners of my riding and the store owners of Bonavista-Trinity-Conception and elsewhere are not exempt from charging the GST on purchases because they are below $20. Why should we give that exemption to U.S. retailers selling through the mail? They can sell all they want. I have no objection providing they operate under the same rules. We should not give an incentive for people to crossborder shop.
It is bad enough that the problem of cross-border shopping exists without us as legislators actually encouraging it. That is the problem I see with what we have done in the past.
We are somewhat attempting to correct it today, but I say to the parliamentary secretary that I hope he and his colleagues will entertain amendments at committee in order to reduce that even more, in order to ensure that the exemption is not $20 but that it only covers those things of nominal value.
It has been estimated that in 1990, $1 billion worth of dutiable and taxable goods came into Canada duty-free as a result of the exemption which I asked to be corrected almost two years ago in this House.
It still has not been done.
Mail orders to the U.S. are increasing at a rate of 30 per cent a year. That is an alarming rate. Thousands of jobs in the retail industry are at risk. It is unfortunate that it took us so long. Again I am glad to see some positive move but the government should have eliminated the exemption altogether, except for things which are of nominal value. If someone sends me a letter in an envelope from the United States I do not expect to pay duty on the fact that the envelope costs 15 cents and the fancy letterhead costs 25 cents. That is obvious. Those things are of nominal value.
For consumer products being shipped in, anything that has more than a nominal value should be taxed, just as we make our own Canadian retailers collect the tax here. No U.S. retailer should be getting a break that we do not give Canadian businesses.
May 13, 1992

Sears Canada, probably the largest mail order company in this country cut down on some of its operation earlier this year. It was in the media everywhere. I do not recall the specific number of jobs but it was extensive.
Mr. Milliken What about Marks & Spencer?
Mr. Boudria My colleague reminds me that only today we heard in the news about the giant retailing operation Marks & Spencer and the difficulties it is suffering right now.
It is not just that store. It is not just that chain. It is the same everywhere in the retail industry.
Allow me to return to McIntyre & Dodd Marketing Inc., which operates out of Hawkesbuiy in my constituency. Some moments ago I reminded the House of the letter in which the president of the company told me that in 1990 it had 165 employees. Today it has 52. That is all caused by this. It said so at the time and the government took way too long to address the problem.
I want to make a few remarks in closing. The parliamentary secretary spoke of the gift exemption. That is an exemption in case your relative or mine in Florida sends a mug in the mail or a small little present saying: "Thinking of you in Florida", so that one does not have to pay duty on those products. Right now that exemption is $40. The government is increasing it to $60 because it says that other nations have exemptions which are $60. That might be so.
However we are a trading nation. We depend a lot on our trade. We import a lot of manufactured products from other countries, and from one country in particular. Therefore we should be particularly cautious in that regard. If the $40 exemption is increased to $60 I predict that some people will use it as a loophole the same as they used the other device.
It is obvious. What do you do? You phone or write your relative in Detroit, in Massena, New York, or in Burlington, Vermont and say: "Dear relative, send me as a 'present' two shirts in the mail or whatever product, and I will send you the cheque later". It is the same thing. We are offering another way for individuals to circumvent the rules. We should not be increasing that exemption from $40 to $60.

We are just making it like the rest of them.

speechtext:
I rest my case.
It says again, and this is the position of the government: "The review of the exemptions for postal and courier imports provided an opportunity to reassess our policy on gifts and to consider the merits of amending the exemption levels to make them more liberal". I did not know this government could make anything more liberal.
It must be an awful strain for them.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
It must be an awful strain on the government.
I am in favour of this government becoming more liberal. Do not get me wrong. As a matter of fact, most of the country is arriving at that conclusion right now, and I appreciate that immensely. I would even accept a vote of confidence from the member across, if he happens to live in my riding, although he probably does not.
The point is that the government is telling us that because it was reviewing the postal and courier import provision it had the opportunity to increase the other. In fact, it is telling us that it is a kind of quid pro quo but it is a quid pro quo that no one on this side of the House asked for. In the last five years not one opposition member has asked for that provision to be changed, has asked for a new loophole to be created. None of us want that.
I say to the parliamentary secretary that when this bill goes before committee he and his colleagues should take the time to rethink that exemption. They should at the very least leave that exemption the way it is. I would even venture to say that it should be lower, but never mind. If they want to leave that particular exemption for gifts at $40 we can probably accept that.
In terms of the $20 exemption on goods sent through the mail, so-called solicited goods, sales through the mail, it is only a small patch on a giant problem. I am
informed in discussions with people here in this House that the L.L. Bean Company, for example, sends catalogues all over the place.
It sends them to virtually anyone who has ever bought anything off shore. It somehow secures those names and then sends these catalogues here. Of course, it is located outside the country and people generally know it.
What about these other outfits that have a "let's pretend" operation in Windsor, Toronto or in an area near the border of the United States? It is only a "let's pretend" operation. There are no jobs there, there is not a group of people doing this. There is only one person who crosses the border to get the mail out of the mail box and then brings it to the other side in order to be able to shift the products from the United States back into Canada afterwards.
There are no jobs for Canadians in that kind of a scam. Meanwhile, this company that kept 165 of my constituents working in 1990 now only has 52 employees, because of that very provision. It exists everywhere.
This one we can measure because it is a mail order company. How do I measure the loss in sales to a store in Hawkesbuiy or Cornwall because of this provision? I cannot. I can measure the mail order house because it is mail order house to mail order house. When the GST came in and the Canadian dollar rose it lost most of its business and had to let go approximately two-thirds of its employees.
I can measure that one but I cannot measure those other jobs lost elsewhere in the retail industry because that provision made it awfully attractive to do what these companies are doing. It was, and McIntyre & Dodd Marketing described it well, a loophole in the system. It was a loophole that was created by the government some years ago. The hon. member for Etobicoke, when he was Minister of Finance, in his first or second budget increased that exemption for reasons which again we do not know.
He created a new industry of people using the loophole in order to displace Canadian jobs. Now we are partially plugging up the loophole, but not totally.
May 13, 1992



In concluding, I want to say that my colleagues and I intend to support the provision in this bill that partly closes the existing loophole for those who ship U.S. merchandise on behalf of a business. However, I fail to see how we could agree to increase exemptions for so-called gifts entering Canada.
I hope that when the bill goes to committee, the government will take this opportunity to consider the amendments I am submitting today on behalf of my colleagues.

Madam Speaker, we have before us one more occasion on which to say that this particular government is obsessed with the symptom rather than the disease when it comes to cross-border shopping.
The government has quite openly spoken about this bill as an attempt to deal with cross-border shopping, and much of what it implements in the details of Bill C-74 is not objectionable in principle in and of itself. I can even imagine that there might be some ambiguity surrounding the arguments put forward by the hon. member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell.
I myself have not had any representations asking for that particular exemption to be increased from $40 to $60, or increased in any way whatsoever. I can also argue that if there is an argument for an exemption period the government might want to increase it from time to time to take account of the reality of price increases, et cetera.
The fact of the matter is that the basic intention of this bill is to deal with a situation that was created in my opinion by a number of things, but first of all and most recently and most dramatically the reality of the GST, the goods and services tax.
If the government were serious about wanting to address the problem of cross-border shopping, it would have to do two or three things. First it has to remove the most prominent reason why people now feel pressured into cross-border shopping in a way that they never did before.
I mean the possibility for cross-border shopping was always there; it is not as if this were just created. The phenomenal increase in cross-border shopping has not just happened in a vacuum. It has happened because of
Government Orders
the GST. It has also happened in my judgment because of the free trade agreement. It is not directly always because of the free trade agreement, but because the free trade agreement has created a mentality or a consciousness among Canadians that the border no longer matters.
The government is telling Canadians through the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, and now the possibility of NAFTA or the North American free trade agreement, that we are moving into a world in which there are no borders and in which capital and corporate agendas are no longer expected to respect in any way the fact that they originate or are located in a particular community and therefore have some accountability for the economic well-being of that community. If they are free to do whatever they like, whatever serves their own immediate economic self-interest, then should it surprise the government that individual Canadians are acting likewise? They are saying that the government has basically used the old maxim many Canadians observed that even though things might have been cheaper in the United States, they still felt some obligation, some moral obligation even, to spend most of their money in Canada and maybe just slip down across the line once a year for the fun of it and pick up a few bargains.
The government has basically told Canadians it is old-fashioned, that it is the kind of attitude one might hear from the NDP or somebody else who is not embracing the new world order of globalization, liberalized trade and global markets. "All this stuff about buying Canadian, looking after your own community and making sure your neighbour has a job is passe. Who cares about that kind of stuff any more? Let's get with it, ladies and gentlemen. Let's get into globalization", which in the short term means Americanization, "and let's look after number one". Whether that number one be an individual, whether that number one be a corporation or whether that number one be a provincial or federal government, all of them are guilty of cross-border shopping in one way or another. From day to day and week to week we find various levels of government have snuck across the border in order to procure certain products, certain services or certain contracts.
Just the other day in Manitoba, for instance, we heard that a local guy who recycles pop bottles is going to go out of business because the provincial government which used to buy this stuff from him is now going to buy it somewhere in the United States. Can we imagine putting Winnipegers out of business because "this is a better

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
deal" for the taxpayer? What kind of bookkeeping is that, what kind of bookkeeping?
This is the problem with everything. There is no sort of megabookkeeping going on so that we can take account of what all these decisions mean in terms of the larger social and economic impact. Instead, there is just one person in one department looking at one set of books and saying: "This is good so let's do it". Whereas if we were looking at the whole set of books we would see that it was not good. The over-all impact of this stinks. It is not good for the community. It is not only not good for the community; in the long term it destroys community because it destroys the very notion that people can move with moral impunity to do whatever they like, whatever serves their own economic self-interest.
I know that I am railing against the idols of the age, but nevertheless this is the way I feel and this is what I see happening here with respect to cross-border shopping. To erect just a few penalties here and there is not going to do the trick, I am sorry. It is not going to do the trick because what needs to be broken is the entire mentality of cross-border shopping.
That mentality got its start with the free trade agreement. Unless that is broken and the way of looking at the world that that involves, I think the government hopes in vain that individual Canadians are somehow going to give up their previous position to act in the way that the government has told people much more powerful than them that it is okay to act.
I will also refer to the whole question of the GST which obviously is a major contributor to this problem, but before doing so I want to say a bit about the high dollar. That is also a problem and that is not unrelated to the free trade agreement.
I am one of those who believe that it is part and parcel of the unwritten agreement that comes with the Cana-da-U.S. Free Trade Agreement that the Canadian dollar will be maintained at a certain level.
I remember Mitchell Sharp, a former Liberal Minister of Finance, coming before the Standing Committee on External Affairs and International Trade in the fall of 1984 and saying to the committee then, when we were studying the elements of the deal, that anyone who thought we would be able to enter into this kind of agreement with the United States and maintain a
70-cent dollar was dreaming in Technicolor. He argued then, and he may still be proved to be right, that some day we would be looking at parity, that the United States would not allow free and open access to its markets from a Canada that had a dollar that was 20 cents or 30 cents lower than its own.
All these things are related, but I have something to say about the GST. It is not as if the GST were an absolute necessity. This is the way it has been portrayed by the government, as some absolute fiscal necessity. It is not an absolute fiscal necessity because there are other ways of raising the money the GST now raises.
For one thing, if we did not have the GST, there is a lot of money we would not have to spend in the first place. There is an enormous amount of money spent collecting the GST in terms of setting up the new administrative costs, the money that the government itself pays in terms of GST and the effect GST has on inflation that in turn has an effect on transfer payments which the federal government has to pay.
If we work out all the costs to the government of the GST, it is not as if we have to replace the entire amount of money the GST now brings in. We only have to replace the difference between what the GST costs the federal government and what the GST brings in.
We have said over and over again to no avail that the Minister of Finance is quite insincere when he says: "Tell us what the alternatives are". We tell him what the alternatives are and he does not even bother to comment on them. Maybe that says something about what he thinks of our alternatives, but the fact is that there have been alternatives put forward and these alternatives have been found unacceptable by the government.
Why have they been found unacceptable by the government? It is because these alternatives would require that the government stand up to its corporate backers in the Business Council on National Issues and demand that the corporate sector in this country pay up, that it fair pays its share and that it forgoes some of the breaks and shelters and loopholes, et cetera, that it now enjoys. We have put this together. I have mentioned them all in the House singly and severally on many occasions, but I mention them again as things which if taken together in some combination could replace the GST.
May 13, 1992

The manufacturing and processing tax credit was created at one point to offset the manufacturers' sales tax. It was eliminated by this government when it brought in the GST but the tax credit stayed. I think that runs up to $1 billion or something like that, at least it did.
The dividend tax credit was designed to avoid double taxation. The fact is that most of the corporations which paid the dividends are not paying any taxes anyway. Instead of preventing double taxation we have no taxation at all.
The intention of the government to renew the tax break for trusts was created in 1972 by the Liberals, which is a renewal of a tax break that would benefit a very small minority of very wealthy Canadian families.
The business and entertainment tax deduction amounts to about $1 billion a year and maybe is one of the best examples of what is wrong with the tax system.
Neil Brooks, who is one of the people heading up the Ontario fair tax commission, was recently quoted in a paper as saying that there is more fraud going on at a Toronto Blue Jays game than there is in any welfare office across the nation because seat after seat after seat at Blue Jays games, hockey games or any other games are bought by corporations. The money that is paid for those seats is tax deductible under the particular measure that I mentioned, the business and entertainment tax deduction, and this money is allegedly spent as part of the cost of doing business. They can deduct the cost of these seats which are given out perhaps in some cases to clients, but in many other cases to family and friends and the Canadian taxpayer pays for this.
People in my riding cannot deduct the 500 bucks they need to buy tools to do their job, which is really a cost of business. They cannot deduct that. However, some big shot in Toronto or elsewhere can deduct the cost of sending his entire family to a Blue Jays game.
You tell me, Madam Speaker, that this is a fair tax system. There is the business and entertainment tax deduction. If the government was looking for a way to at
Government Orders
least chip away at its fiscal problems, it could have looked at that. The government did not. It would not do that, no, sir.
Then there is the whole question of capital gains. One of the things that I found most offensive in life here as a member of Parliament was in 1985. It was the first Conservative budget when the half a million dollar lifetime capital gains tax exemption was announced and the whole Tory backbench rose as one in standing ovation as if this was the greatest thing that ever happened. This was the highlight of their political lives. What a wonderful thing, what a wonderful break. For whom? Not for anyone in my riding.
Obviously for many of the people who are the movers and the shakers over there, this was a wonderful thing. This was orgasmic. I have never seen anything like it. The Conservatives have since moved to reduce it. They moved in the last budget to reduce it again, except in the wrong way.
We have always maintained that the capital gains tax exemption should exist to a certain extent for principal residences, for small businesses and for farms. One of the other dimensions of personal residences, if you like, at least as far as I am concerned, is the family cottage.
What did the Tory government decide to do about capital gains? If you are making money in the marketplace you can still write that off against your capital gains tax exemption.
The government is going to go after the family cottage, the family camp, because the government is tough. Let us go after all those individual cottage owners who have had cottages for years and may now want to pass it on to another generation through an actual sale; the Tories will get them, they will nail them.
In the meantime the big boys will continue to do whatever they like. That is Tory tax reform; get more from the little guy. The evidence mounts week after week, month after month, that under this government the ordinary Canadian is paying more and more and more taxes. The evidence also shows that the people at the very top are paying less taxes.

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
Where I come from that is wrong, plain old-fashioned wrong, just as it is plain old-fashioned wrong to screw your own country whether you are a provincial government or a company or an individual by spending all your money somewhere else. I know that is old-fashioned. I know I am sounding like some kind of antique around here but I do not apologize for that.
What else could we have used to offset the alleged need for the GST? There is the interest deductibility rule by which companies borrow money in Canada, write off the interest in their taxes so they can buy up Canadian companies and put them out of business. This is great. We are financing all this. All this so-called new investment in Canada is actually money borrowed in Canada, accompanied by a tax break, to put Canada out of business. We are the only country in the world foolish enough to finance our own extinction. We could look at that.
As I implied a few minutes ago, we could look at making the income tax system more progressive, even just making it as progressive as it used to be. It used to be the case that somebody who made $50,000 did not pay the same rate as somebody who made $450,000. No, the Tories have said, "Tory tax reform. There is no distinction to be made between somebody who makes $50,000 and somebody who makes $450,000. They are all the same". I do not think so, Canadians never thought so, and Canadians never asked for a tax system that did not make those kinds of distinctions.
We could also look at some kind of wealth tax or inheritance tax beyond a certain limit. This has to be done federally because provincial governments simply cannot do it. They end up competing with each other as they did when this particular kind of tax was given to the provincial jurisdiction in the early 1970s and eventually no one has the tax at all. People who would be the target of such a tax, who have a lot of money, are the very same kind of people who are very skilled in moving their money around.
I could talk about the money that could have been raised and still could be raised by a green tax which would not only have the effect of raising money but of discouraging environmentally unfriendly behaviour and products. There are all kinds of ways that the government could do otherwise than maintain the GST. If it wanted to do that, that is eliminate the GST, it would not
have to come forward with bills like this which basically do very little to address a symptom of a larger problem than the larger disease which is both the GST and the free trade agreement.

Madam Speaker, the bill we have before us today in this House is an effort by the government to deal with a very serious economic problem that Canada has, the problem of cross-border shopping.
Since free trade came in, businesses in many parts of Canada have been decimated. People from the lower mainland in British Columbia go to the United States, to Seattle, on a regular basis to do their shopping. When you go to places such as Windsor, Wallaceburg, Sarnia, the area near Detroit, the Niagara peninsula, Kingston; all along that border right into the maritimes, wherever there are populations along our border the problem of cross-border shopping is decimating Canadian communities. Retail stores are closing down. It is reflected in the high unemployment figures in Canada, unemployment figures which have spiralled.
The phenomenon has been described to our Liberal task force on deindustrialization by many concerned municipalities. They talk about how major shopping plazas are closing down. Major retailers are then moving out. The people are left without work. What do they say are the causes of this cross-border shopping? First of all and number one, the Canadian taxes on gasoline and diesel fuel.
We talked to a trucker who, in the past six months, had not purchased any of his diesel fuel in Canada. He always crossed the border to do that.
Another cause of course is the higher taxes in Canada on cigarettes and liquor.
Third, people talked about the higher taxes and higher costs of some of the foods in Canada. But the two main things were our taxes on gas and on diesel fuel and the taxes we impose on alcohol and cigarettes.
I am not arguing that smokers or drinkers should have an easier ride, but we are living in a world that this government took us full square into through the free trade agreement. It gave it to us. It must have foreseen the consequences of the thousands upon thousands of lost jobs and the billions of dollars in lost sales every year because of this phenomenon.
May 13, 1992

We cannot ask Canadians to be patriotic when they are only doing what the government told them to do: shop in the United States, that is fine, that is what free trade is all about. We heard the Conservative speeches when they were telling us about free trade and how it was going to be good for us. Even if we are patriotic Canadians, we just do not have money to throw away when we can buy a lot of these goods cheaper across the border. We have been bringing this issue to the attention of the government for a long time.
Finally the Minister of National Revenue reacted. I am glad he reacted, but did he deal with the number one issue, the taxes on gasoline and diesel fuel? He did not touch it in this bill. Our truckers in Canada suffer a 20 per cent to 25 per cent cost disadvantage vis-a-vis their American counterparts.
A lot of these truckers are small, independent people who own their own rigs. They have big mortgages on them. They cannot compete with companies like Hunt that come up from the southern states where the wages are so low and the actual cost of buying a truck is less. The depreciation on trucks for tax purposes is more, as well as all of the advantages they have on repairs and the costs of tires and things like that. The facts were there. They did not touch this particular issue.
Canadians still get an advantage out of going to the United States to buy their gasoline. You fill up, it becomes a ritual. You go there once a week to fill up with gas and at the same time you fill up with a lot of other things.
Let me talk about one other aspect of this whole cross-border shopping phenomenon that is very devastating to Canada. It is the Canadian mail order direct marketing industry. We had in place before this bill a law which said that American mail order firms could sell into Canada and if the value of the goods was under $40 there would be no Canadian duty, no Canadian excise tax, no Canadian tariffs, no GST and no provincial sales tax.
Is that fair? If they were buying in Canada from a Canadian these things would have to be paid. It is patently obvious that there was not a level playing field between U.S. mail order houses and Canadian retailers.
Government Orders
As well, there was not a level playing field for Canada's direct mail order industry because when we sold to Americans by mail order the Americans did not say: "Ho, ho, free ride". They said: "You will pay about $10 Canadian in fees, postal processing fees and inspection fees". Every mail order that went from Canada to the United States was tagged with a $10 U.S. fee.
What has the minister done in this bill to create a level playing field between Canadian retailers and U.S. mail order people and between Canadian mail order people and U.S. mail order people? In this bill he has done two things. First, he has reduced the exemption level from $40 to $20. It is a good move. We agree with lowering that threshold and we appreciate the efforts of the government to try to deal with it. However, we ask whether the government went far enough. Should it not have gone further? Should it have lowered the exemption to the neighbourhood of $5 where the handling and other fees would not have been adequate to deal with it? At that level there would not have been the incentive.
We know that there are certain people who are prepared to take advantage of this $20 loophole. For example, if you want to order from some U.S. direct mail order house, such as L. L. Bean, and you want a radio that costs $15, a shirt that costs $18, and a pair of pants that costs $17 you do not order them all together. You can get them shipped individually. That is one way to do it. That way you avoid the Canadian taxes and duties, the GST.
As well, there are cases in which a U.S. mail order house pretends that it actually has a Canadian arm, that it is a Canadian company because it has a postal box in Canada. It advertises all sorts of goods and asks us to send our orders to a postal box in Windsor. Even if a Canadian is trying to be patriotic and buy Canadian they can get caught by the postal box syndrome.
The U.S. company can then pick up the orders and mail them back into Canada. It can avoid all the taxes by splitting the orders so that there is nothing over $20 in any one package.
This bill is an effort that is reasonable but it does not go far enough. What is even more shocking is that it has now imposed a $5 mail processing fee on U.S. mail orders coming into Canada.

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
Why did the government not do what we asked it to do before and impose a fee of $10? That is what the U.S. charges Canadian mail order firms selling to Americans. Why did it not give us a level playing field?
I do not know the reason. Our Canadian mail order industry has lost 4,000 jobs in six years. It calculates it has lost $260 million in sales just because of that disparity of the U.S. imposing a $10 fee and Canada imposing nothing. Again, it is a half measure.
We now have a $5 fee but the Americans are still charging us $10. Is that a level playing field? Why did the government not give us the extra $5 so that Canadians had a chance? I wish someone in the government could explain this to me.
I give the Minister of National Revenue all the credit for good intentions in dealing with the issue. He finally heard what we were saying about the devastating impact of cross-border shopping but his measures obviously could not have been undertaken in consultation with the people most affected.
Did he talk to the truckers about why they still go to the United States to fill their tanks with diesel fuel? Did he ask why cross-border shopping has become a family ritual for people living within 50 miles of the border in the last three years? Did he ask why there are now tour companies in metropolitan Toronto which organize bus excursions not to see Niagara Falls, New York, or plays in New York but to go shopping.
They have been doing it for a long time.

Yes, they have been doing this for a long time, but the Minister of State for Finance and Privatization must admit that cross-border shopping has increased incredibly over the last few years. He knows that.
The member from near the Chatham area knows what is happening in his community simply because people now have changed their shopping patterns.
Was this anticipated as part of the free trade agreement? If it was, why has the government not done something about it? If it was not anticipated, why was the homework not done? Maybe the government did not believe its own rhetoric that Canadians would be able to
go down to the United States and get all these goodies duty free.
Maybe it did not want them to. Maybe it hoped they would not do it. However, this measure we are facing today to attempt to undo some of the damage already caused to Canada is a measure which, at best, goes only halfway. Another thing that the government has tried to do is to increase the amount on gifts that can come in from United States duty, tax, and provincial sales tax-free from $40 to $60.
Why increase gifts that come duty-free from the States? What is the point? Is it to help Canadians who want to get gifts from their families in the United States? Perhaps, but is this good? Does this create any jobs in Canada? Does this help our retailing industry in Canada? Does this help Canadian producers in any way?
What is the idea behind increasing the amount of gifts from the United States into Canada that is duty-free from $40 to $60? There are already enough exemptions when people do go to the United States themselves. They can bring in $300 every three months, or whatever. They have increased these limits.
Are we really saying to Canadians: "We want you to get more from the United States?" How does this square with the government's so-called buy Canada program? This buy Canada program, which we have not seen the details of yet, was one of the major recommendations of our task force on deindustrialization. However, if the government is going to ask Canadians to support Canadian products and Canadian producers, is this bill before us not in conflict with that principle? It is not running on all fours with it. It has not gone far enough in closing some of the loopholes we have seen.
I would like to ask the minister why he did not recommend to cabinet that we deal with the real causes of cross-border shopping. As we heard in testimony from the mayors of the communities that are devastated, it has something to do with the taxes on fuels.
The government did try to deal with something in terms of cigarettes. What did it do? It said: "We have a problem with Canadian cigarettes going into the United States and then being smuggled back into Canada. We are pretty bright. What we will do is stop up this loophole. We will impose a tax when they leave Canada".
May 13, 1992

That means if you are buying cigarettes you can buy Canadian cigarettes on which the duty has already been paid, so they are a lot more expensive in the U.S. stores, or you have the option of buying American cigarettes which have not had this duty levied on them, so they are a lot cheaper. What was the Canadian shopper going to the United States going to do? Is she or he going to buy the Canadian cigarettes that are duty paid and are a heck of a lot more expensive or buy American cigarettes? It was obvious. The government had it backward.
The government had to back down on that tax, and thank goodness it did. I give it credit for listening. It took a lot of coaching and a lot of cajoling. It took the tobacco industry saying to the government: "Hey, you are going to hurt Canadian tobacco sales and we are going to move our operations out of Canada because we can no longer compete because you have these screwy taxes". The government listened. The hon. member for Lambton- Middlesex, the hon. member from Chatham and others said: "Your tax is screwy. It does not work. It is backwards".
Thank goodness, I give the government credit. It listened and it backed off.
However, did the government do anything about another major cause of cross-border shopping which is that during the short period of two or three years the dollar went from under 80 cents, 76 or 78 cents, up to 90 cents U.S.? That gave Canadians a 12 percentage point premium to shop in the United States. It made their imports from the United States 12 percentage points cheaper.
Did the government realize this when it was exercising its very tough monetary control and putting interest rates up to record highs in terms of real interest in Canada? The real interest rates under this government were higher even than the real interest rates in 1981 and 1982 when actual interest rates hit 22 per cent. This government in its obsession with dealing with inflation was prepared to drive up interest rates, drive up the dollar, make us non-competitive and hurt our exporting industries. That exacerbated the cross-border shopping problem.
We are glad that the dollar is coming down, and it should go down lower. However, real interest rates in
Government Orders
Canada are still very high, they are still a lot higher than in the United States. When this government chose, for all Canadians, to get into bed with the Americans surely it realized that we had to have a level playing field. However, did it give that to us? We have had a high tax, high dollar, and high interest rate policy which has made competition very difficult. These were anchors around the necks of Canadian producers.
I know my time is running out. In conclusion, government is dealing with the issue, but government is not dealing with it to the full extent that it needs to be dealt with. What have been brought in are half measures at best. We urge government to reconsider what it is proposing and to deal with the real issues.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to reply to some of the questions that were posed by my hon. friend.
First of all, in all fairness when we are talking about cross-border shopping it is a very complicated matter. It not only involves the federal government but it involves provincial and municipal governments as well.
Municipal tax bills are far less in the United States. Therefore, businesses are paying less overhead. One reason-and we cannot argue with this-is that teachers are paid twice as much in St. Catharines as they are in Buffalo. That ends up on the municipal tax bill. Our retailers have to pay that. I am not saying that we lower salaries to teachers, but I want to make the point that in comparing these things we have to be very careful.
The hon. member is the brother of a former provincial premier who raised taxes on gasoline and cigarettes. So did the federal government. The provinces play a very important role in this as well. Municipalities, provinces, federal government, they all play very important roles.
By the way, I have no sympathy for the people who buy their cigarettes in the United States and get their lung transplants in Canada, or who buy their booze in the United States and get their liver transplants in Canada. The same ones who shop in the United States come back here and complain about medical services they might or might not be able to get here.

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
I have a very difficult time with that, where they buy their products in the United States and then come back here to Canada and demand all the services. I have a difficult time with that, so let us make it clear where I am coming from.
To answer some of the specific questions that the hon. member posed to me during his speech, he mentioned when we lowered the limit from $40 to $20. As you will remember, Mr. Speaker, it was at $20 for many years and was raised to $40 to try to take away some of the administrative problems.
Let me put this in perspective. In lowering it from $40 to $20, the post office has to deal with 5 million packages a year. That is 5 million packages it has to check to make sure that the value is correct. We are asking the post office to do that. If it was lowered by his suggestion from $20 to a $5 limit on a package, another 9 million packages would have to be checked. It is a tremendous expense to check these packages to make sure they are in fact within the proper limit. The hon. member should take that into consideration.
The $5 fee is a handling fee. The post office said: "We will do this work for you but it is going to cost us a lot of money and we need a $5 fee in order to examine these packages to ensure that in fact they meet those dollar limits".

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext: It is also a further deterrent.

That is right. It is a further deterrent, but it is there for a purpose.
The free trade agreement and duties have nothing to do with cross-border shopping. We have our limits as to what we can purchase there. Then when we bring the product in, we have to pay the sales tax on it, if it is over and above the limit.
We are supposed to pay the provincial and federal sales tax on it at the border plus any tariffs that are still on it, over the exemptions that people are allowed. The exemptions are: $300 in one year; $100 after having been out of the country for 48 hours; and the $20 incidental after 24 hours. That is important.
As far as the gift exemption is concerned, I think this is important also. The United States gift exemption is $50 U.S. into the United States; ours is $60, which is fairly comparable. If we are shipping gifts into the European Community, the exemption allowed is $72 Canadian.
They are a little more generous than we are, but it is all in the same ball park. It is fairly close as far as gifts are concerned.
I want to comment on one last thing, if I might, because he asked a series of questions that should be answered.
He gave the example of the American mail order firms using Canadian addresses. As of July 1, Customs will not allow American mail order firms to use Canadian addresses. So that problem has been answered as well.
I hope I have answered the questions that my hon. friend has presented today. We have looked into those suggestions that he made and found that especially lowering it from $20 to $5 would make a tremendous cost to the Canadian taxpayer for handling those types of problems.

Mr. Speaker, I have two comments concerning what the minister said. First of all, he tried to distance himself from his government and his government's policies by saying that he personally has no sympathy for people who go to the United States, buy alcohol and come back to Canada to get liver transplants.
Nobody has sympathy for that. But what is happening is that this government's policies encourage it. That is what is happening. The government's policies encourage it because our tax rates and therefore the cost of alcohol and cigarettes-and I am not making a case for people using either-are so much higher, just as they are for gasoline. I am not saying that people should buy gasoline there but some people do. They go to the United States because it is so much cheaper.
Your party supports that.

I am sorry. We have consistently said the government has not dealt with the major causes of cross-border shopping. This government's tax levels encourage people to go to the United States to buy those things.
Your party supports that.

The government is the author of a program-it has been in government eight years-of free trade plus going to the United States to buy these things that people buy. Tell me how it helps Canada when a trucker has not bought his diesel fuel in Canada for the last six months.
We don't have the diesel fuel, the province does.
It is the province's fault.
Check your facts.

I know, I know. If it is not the government's fault then it is the Liberals' fault because we were in government until 1984. It is the provinces' fault because they impose taxes. Yes, they do impose taxes. And I will tell you why they are imposing more and more taxes. It is because the transfer payments from the feds to the provinces have been chopped and cut.
Let me say this. Ceilings. What are ceilings for? To cut the rate increase.
Ceilings?

Mr. Speaker, does the hon. minister have the floor? I know he gets veiy excited but I would encourage him to bring to the House the decorum he expects from all other members.
The hon. minister said that the government has done a marvellous thing by imposing a $5 fee on U.S. mail orders coming into Canada. This is an administrative fee to reimburse the post office for its costs of looking at these packages and determining values.
Do you know what, Mr. Speaker? Good. The post office is being reimbursed $5 and the United States post office is reimbursed $10 if a Canadian mail order house is trying to sell to the Americans. Why did the government not give us a level playing field when it knew what the problem was, when it was told that because of not having that $10 comparable fee it cost our mail order houses in Canada about $260 million in lost sales and 4,000 lost jobs over six years?
We were told. Why did the government not impose the same level as the Americans? They charge $10 Canadian and we are now only charging them $5. Are we out to help the Americans? Was that deliberate? Is the government deliberately trying to help them or was it just stupid? What was it?

My question is for my hon. colleague. We have just seen a lot of hot air escape from the government benches. We have seen a lot of theatrics over there but I want to get back to the
Government Orders
reality of the day. We are not going to be side-tracked by this type of nonsense from the government benches.
It appears to me the fact of the matter is that people are being driven south of the border. They either request goods through United States mail order catalogues or they drive across the border to get gasoline. Or, those who live in a border area go over on a daily basis to pick up milk and bread and whatever else they need.
Since the minister has such an aversion to those other vices, let us talk about food that they go over and pick up on a daily basis.
There is an awful noise coming from the other side. There is an awful noise coming from the minister. Perhaps if he would like the floor he can get the Speaker's attention.
The point that I was trying to make is that it appears the drive across the border is being encouraged by the Prime Minister and his Minister of Finance, who have not been able to come to grips with the horrendous tax problems we find in our system vis-a-vis the United States. Perhaps my hon. colleague can address the real problem that the bag of wind on the other side obviously omits.

I thank the member for Dartmouth. Of course, taxes in Canada under this Toiy regime have gone up 33 times in eight years. Now, I suppose that is our fault because we were the government before. Okay. The government should accept responsibility for what it has done.
Now, with the cost of food, this government supposedly is supporting farm marketing boards. Is it going to support our farm marketing boards for which we know Canadian consumers are happy to pay a little bit extra? But, do not pretend that they will not go to the United States to buy some of these goods as well.
The government must accept responsibility.

Mr. Speaker, this is an appropriate time for us to talk about the problems this government has caused vis-a-vis the flood of people and capital out of this country.
There are some provisions in the bill before us that we support and indeed that we have called for and the government has finally listened, albeit perhaps too late.

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
And there are some other provisions in this bill that we simply do not support because we think they are contradictory to the spirit of the first part of the bill.
One does not have to be a genius to sit down and figure out that Canadians do not voluntarily allow their capital to leave the country, knowing full well that each time they go across a border and buy goods in the United States of America as opposed to their local home town the impact of that is going to be lost jobs and lost revenue to border communities.
We know full well that Canadians probably do not consciously sit down and say: "If I order from L. L. Bean instead of going to Sears in Halifax"-when Sears used to have an order office in Halifax-"it is going to take away from revenues, is going to take away from the quality of life in my community because dollars are going to be leaving and we are going to be shipping it over to the good old U.S.A." They do not consciously do that. If they had their druthers, I do not think that they would do it.
But the fact of life is that over the last number of years this tired old government has made too many promises about tax reform that it simply has not been able to fulfil.
I remember way back when I was just a member of the public, listening to all the promises made by the Prime Minister opposite and his members of the government when they talked about fundamentally changing the face of Canada. I remember clearly the Prime Minister said: "Give me four years and you won't recognize this country".
The border communities know what he meant, because those border communities now know that they cannot recognize their main streets any more. When going down the main streets of border communities one will find place after place vacated. There are notices of sheriff's sales and bankruptcy signs in the windows. This is because of this government's economic and tax policies.
I know full well that Canadians are very different from Americans. As Canadians, we try to do things differently and we try to support each other. If things cost a little more in Canada for the quality of life that we have, then
so be it. I think most Canadians, if they had the resources to be generous in that direction, would accept that.
What has happened successively over the last eight years, most important the last three and a half years, is this government has abandoned and betrayed every single promise that it has made to the middle class of Canada and to those below the middle class, those below poverty level, that it is going to ensure there is a more equitable tax system in Canada. The problems this bill seeks to address are real. The problems this bill seeks to address have been caused 100 per cent by this government's tax policy and this government's economic policy. I think we have to recognize that on all sides of this House.
The government has come in with a regime of taxation which over a period of time has increased the over-all tax burden on the middle class. Believe it or not, most people who are cross-border or mail order shopping are not the people living below the poverty line. They are not the people who are making $14,000 a year living in Dartmouth, Welland, or anywhere else in this country who are trying to keep a roof over their head and trying to keep their children fed, clean, and clothed. They are not the people. The people who are doing this are the people in the middle class. They are the people who are feeling the pinch harder than they have ever felt it before because of this government's policies. We all remember the promises of fundamental tax reform and we have seen what the Tories mean when they say fundamental tax reform. You can also read that to mean we are going to take more from you and we are going to give you less back by way of services.
My hon. colleague from Ontario has just indicated that over the last number of years this bunch opposite has increased taxes 33 times. There have been 33 tax increases. If you listen to the group opposite, you would think they had reduced taxes by 30 per cent when they talk about their agenda for economic change, how they are going to inflict prosperity on all Canadians.
What the government has done by its economic policies is inflict poverty on far too many Canadians. It has inflicted hardship on far too many Canadians and the only prosperity it inflicted on anybody is on American

companies that live in the border areas in the United States. That is the only prosperity it has effected.
It came in with free trade which has closed factories in and around our border areas. All through southwestern Ontario the manufacturing base has been absolutely devastated by this government's free trade deal.
I hope everybody has a good memory out there. Another broken promise: Free trade is going to bring thousands of jobs to Canada, prosperity is around the comer. I heard the Prime Minister saying that when I was running against a Conservative. I told people they should not listen to him. They listened to what I had to say and they listened to the Liberals in Atlantic Canada.
And you lied to them.

Excuse me. Did I hear a member opposite say that I lied to somebody? You had better be careful with your words. I will stand up to anything that I said to my electorate, and I hope the Prime Minister and you and your group opposite will be able to do the same thing. If you get up and you tell the public what you promised them back in 1988 and you stand on your record, each and every one of you will have another job the next time the Canadian public has a chance to eke out their judgment on your record.
There is no question at all that the Prime Minister and his gang opposite promised generous assistance programs. The member opposite might want to forget this one. If I were a Tory I would. We were going to have the most generous assistance programs, adjustment programs, ever with free trade. The ministers opposite, time and time again-

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I am enjoying my hon. friend's rhetoric but I see no relevance whatsoever in his remarks to the bill before the House.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I appreciate the fact the hon. member has brought this to my attention.

Mr. Speaker, I will make it very relevant. The reason people are availing themselves of mail order houses across the border is precisely because the government has put them in a position where they can no longer afford to buy Canadian made goods. I cannot put it any more succinctly than that.
Government Orders
Even my colleague from South Shore who sometimes has great difficulty with comprehending what Canadians are saying, not just in my riding, is having trouble comprehending the message they are sending him and his government in his riding. He knows full well the cause of cross-border shopping is economic. It is economic because of a tax regime this government has put in.
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Gentlemen, please. I would ask for a little decorum so that we can hear each other speak in debate.

Mr. Speaker, I know my hon. friend opposite gets very agitated when he hears the truth, so I understand some of his problems this evening.
To speak specifically to the bill, what this bill seeks to do is address a problem indirectly. That problem is to try to stop the cross-border mail order shopping that goes on that has cost Canadian businesses millions of dollars in lost revenue and has cost thousands of jobs in Canada.
I think the measure to drop the amount that can come across the border from $40 to $20 is indeed a good measure, but perhaps it comes a little too late. I think of what happened at the Sears catalogue office in Halifax. The Sears catalogue office in Halifax, because of reduced orders that were coming in, made a decision that it had to rationalize its Canadian operations. It shut down the mail order office in Halifax and put that in Belleville. That is wonderful for the people of Belleville and I hope that they enjoy their new jobs, but I will tell you that for the hundreds of people who lost their jobs in Halifax-Dartmouth, these types of measures are too little and much, much too late. To close the bam door after they let the horse out, as my father would say, is a pretty stupid thing to do.
We on this side of the House have said consistently over the last number of months that the government's economic policies and taxation policies were driving money across the border and driving jobs across the border.
