We agree with the government that finally the limit of goods that can come in from those mail order houses has been reduced from $40 to $20, but I just wonder how many parcels valued at $60 are now going to come across

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
in three different packages of $20. That is something that we still have to address and this bill does not.
There is another part of the bill that I simply think is ludicrous. The minister of state tried to get up and justify it. He is the great justifier of all the government's deeds in the House here, as we know. He said: "Well, you know, we are trying to harmonize". Every time I hear harmonize I think of 100, 200 or 300 jobs leaving the country. Every time this government harmonizes, workers shudder because right after harmonization comes pink slips and UIC, albeit they cannot get as much as they used to because the gang opposite even changed that program, for goodness sake.
This measure says that goods valued at $40 which used to be able to come in without any problem are now going to be reduced to $20, but on the other hand gifts that are coming in on non-commercial carriers across the border now go up, from $40 to $60. I guess if a fellow really wanted, because his pay packet kept getting less every day because the government's tax bite keeps getting bigger, to get around the rules, I suspect at least in Atlantic Canada, he would have all kinds of opportunities.
In the last little while in Atlantic Canada there probably have been more individuals who have had to leave Atlantic Canada and go to other parts of the country. Maybe they can zip over and mail some stuff across as a gift, I do not know. I suspect that is against the spirit of the law. There have been many exoduses of Atlantic Canadians. Nearly everybody in Atlantic Canada has got somebody down in Boston whom they visit. To take it from $40 to $60 I think makes a mockery of the first provision, which was to increase for mail order houses the amount that can come across scot-free from $20 to $40.
This earlier provision, the reduction from $40 to $20, is one that I can support. I think it starts to address the problem, but there are all kinds of other problems. There is a problem, as my hon. colleague from Ontario said, dealing with taxation, with the price of the excise tax on gasoline.
The minister of state was quick to bellow out from his place-my God he was jumping up and down like a
jack-in-the-box-to remind my colleague that excise taxes are provincial. I think that is correct, they are provincial, but let us look at this because that is a problem as well for the loss of dollars from cross-border shopping. I think this is relevant. If the minister could get up in his questions and raise taxation policy at a provincial level, my hon. colleague from South Shore might see that I am as relevant in this as the minister was when he was answering a few minutes ago. If you deal with that type of problem, you will very quickly see the reason for the federal government deficit.
Federal government members like to stand up and say that their deficit is at $30 billion or $31 billion, as if we are all supposed to get real happy over that. It is at $30 billion or $31 billion and even in this worst recession we have had since the depression, it has been able to hold the line.
There is another figure that Canadians should know. It is that the cumulative provincial deficit in 1988-89 was about $4.1 billion. Because of this government's economic policy, because of a series of tax increases, by capping transfers to provinces, by slowing the rate of growth in program expenditure, it has effectively caused the cumulative provincial deficits in Canada to go from $4.1 billion in 1988-89 to an estimated $24.1 billion this year.
The hon. minister might get up and play a little shell game and say: "It is not our fault". This government has mismanaged the economy badly, and then with a sleight of hand it has transferred its mismanagement on to the backs of the poorest provinces. Those provinces are faced with a much reduced tax base. Unfortunately some of them have had to go to the sin tax, like gasoline and excise taxes, to try to maintain quality programs in health care and education.
I do not need any lessons from the minister about where the root of the problem is. The root of the problem lies in about 38 people on the other side who surround the Prime Minister, who have lost all sense of direction as to where they think they are taking this country. The problem lies in a tax system that favours Canadians purchasing goods from Americans as opposed to Canadians. The problem lies with a government that was so hell bent on lying in bed with the Americans that it passed a flawed trade deal.

This bill gives and takes. It goes forward two steps and falls back three, but that is almost the best record I have seen from this government in a long time.
In conclusion, I would hope that the government, in the waning hours of its mandate, in the dying days of Toiydom in 1992, will do a little mea culpa and look at some of the other problems it has perpetrated upon the Canadian people and come in with some measures to offer relief to those Canadian retailers and consumers who have been battered so badly by their economic agenda.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I notice we have now heard from three Liberal members and one New Democrat. In the case of all four, when they have spoken on this bill, they have supported it. They have supported the measures in it.
I listened with care to my hon. friend from Dartmouth.
I am pleased to see that the hon. member from Stratford is here because after a performance like that he may wish to commend the hon. member for Dartmouth for a summer position at the theatre in Stratford.
My hon. friend, like his colleague before him, spoke about cross-border shopping and the issue in the context of the free trade agreement and the context of the policies of this government. I think it is important and time that people recognized that cross-border shopping and the fact that it exists, more than anything else, proves the wisdom of what this government has been saying about competitiveness.
Why do people shop in the United States? They shop in the United States because they believe they are going to get a better deal, and sometimes they do. Sometimes they do not, mind you, but they have been convinced in some circumstances that they will get a better deal over there. In many instances, they shop there because they get a better price.
My hon. friend would like to say that the reason the prices are better in the United States is because of the policies of this government. That is a lot of nonsense and I suspect, because I know he is a very intelligent man, he probably knows that. He is just playing politics with the issue. I guess that is what sometimes goes on here.
Government Orders
This government has been saying that our businesses have got to get themselves to the point where they can compete on an economic basis. Some of the problem- my friend would probably say most of the problem-has to do with levels of taxation in this country. We do have higher taxes in this country in many respects. Some of them are federal taxes. Some of them are provincial taxes. Indeed, some of them are municipal taxes.
The hon. minister of state commented earlier on the levels of municipal taxes directly related to the cost of education, because of the level of teachers' salaries here as compared to the United States, as an illustration. The same could be said with respect to the cost of health services in this country and the fact that Canadians want those services. Granted there is a problem. If somebody says: "I want the benefits of the Canadian health services, but I am going take advantage of the lower taxation levels in the United States", that is an issue, with all due respect, that my hon. friend can hardly with any logical reason lay at the feet of this government because those issues are totally unrelated.
We heard talk earlier from the hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona with respect to the high Canadian dollar. We had a very low Canadian dollar and what advantage did Canadian business take of it? Did they use that as an opportunity to improve their competitiveness? No, that margin was squandered. One of the reasons why the Canadian dollar has risen is because of the confidence the international community has in this country. That is one of the reasons the pinch is there and things are not quite so easy.
I am coming to my final point with this document I received in the mail. For the second time this year I received a letter from the Liberal Party of Canada asking for my financial support. The reason it wants my financial support, it tells me, is that I can help get rid of this government and I quote from this letter:
"You can help elect the party that is prepared to institute an economic plan to benefit all Canadians". Later on the letter says: "We must establish a fair taxation system based on an individual's ability to pay. We must replace the totally unfair GST". Who pays the GST? We all pay the GST. People who spend more money pay more GST. People in the lower economic

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
strata are shielded from the impact of the GST by the GST credit.
Yet we are told that these are the people who are going to bring us an economic program with fair taxation. I listened with interest to what my hon. friend said. I read with interest this letter of solicitation from the Liberal Party of Canada to me. The Liberals can take me off the mailing list. I am not going to vote in the leadership in Nova Scotia. I am not going to send money to the Liberal Party because this country already has the best government it is going to have for quite some time and I look forward to the election next year.

Mr. Speaker, my hon. colleague said that I should be in Stratford, or at least he thinks my abilities might be useful there. If that is the best he can do I would urge him to take more lessons.
I cannot believe that the member actually got up in this debate and tried to tell people that the GST has been a positive thing for people on low incomes .Either the member is so blinded by his party's own rhetoric when it comes to the goods and service tax or he does not speak to the people in his riding who live in poverty.
Only a Conservative member from the south shore of Nova Scotia would get up and brag about a tax that has pushed more businesses into bankruptcy, that has cost the Canadian economy, small businesses in Canada, $10 billion in thi first year according to the CFIB.
We are living in a time when we have had record bankruptcies. Over 60,000 Canadians and over 16,000 Canadian businesses were driven into bankruptcy because of misguided tax policies such as the GST. Only a Tory from the south shore of Nova Scotia would get up in front of the public of Canada, but more importantly his constituents, and say bold-facedly that he supports the very economic activities and programs that have thrown his own constituents out of work.
The former chair of the finance committee said one day to a group outside the House: "There are a lot of us who can talk our way into this place, but once you get here you should learn something because you can also talk your way out of the place". I would leave that advice with my hon. colleague opposite when he starts talking about the wonderful impact of his government's economic policies on his own constituents.

Mr. Speaker, just a comment and then a question.
On May 8 the minister for tourism announced a new $3 million program. The title of it was "Tourism Canada's new campaign reminds Canadians". The government is spending $3 million to remind Canadians to stay in Canada. That is all very well and good. Most of the reasons we are not having tourists coming into Canada is because of the GST that has been put on-

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext: What does this have to do with Bill C-74?

Just hold your horses. What I am saying, Mr. Speaker, is that in the newspaper yesterday I was looking at "Canada 125, Buy Canadian".
This government put the GST on goods here in Canada which forces Canadians to go to the United States to buy. I would think that if the hon. member for South Shore asked his Minister of Finance to take away the GST on goods here in Canada there might be less cross-border shopping. There would be less need to go across the border or have mail orders sent out to bring goods back. In that way we would help our big major companies across Canada as well as the small companies that are hurting. It is a known fact they are hurting because of the GST.
I ask the hon. member for Dartmouth whether or not he thinks that it would be wiser to have the GST taken off for travellers coming into Canada to help our tourism. Also, does he not think the tax should be taken off gas, off cigarettes and off the common goods that Canadians go across in order to buy? Would that not be more reasonable than lowering it to $20 and up to $60 on the other side?

Mr. Speaker, the comments that my hon. colleague has made point once again to the complexity of the disaster that the government has perpetrated upon Canadian retailers and upon Canadian consumers.
It has brought in a tax system, and the hon. member opposite me might not like to hear this, which is so badly flawed, which is so highly complex that it literally has been driving businesses and dollars to the United States. At the same time the flip side of this nightmare that it has created on every street in Canada is not only does it drive Canadian dollars south of the border, but it ensures
May 13, 1992

that tourists from the U.S. are less likely to come north of the border. It is a double-edged sword, each side of which is equally lethal to Canadian businesses.
My hon. colleague from South West Nova knows full well the impact that the GST and other tax measures have had on cross-border shopping in reverse. Crossborder shopping in reverse is when Americans come up to see the beautiful country that we have, places like Meteghan, Yarmouth, Clare and Digby. They used to come across on the ferries. But because of that double-edged sword which drives Canadians south to purchase through mail order houses, they are not coming up in the numbers they used to. It has a double impact. It is like a big spiral.
People are being laid off in the tourism industry in her riding. When the Americans do not come and spend, her people do not have the money to buy Canadian. That starts the cycle again and they pick up an L. L. Bean catalogue instead of a Sears catalogue because the goods in it are a few pennies cheaper and they add to the problem. It is vicious cycle which people in her riding have been driven into by this government's policy.
In conclusion, I am glad that she entered into the debate. She is protecting the interests of the people in her constituency, as the member for South Shore should be doing. Maybe then he would be less reckless in his rhetoric.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to come at this bill from a different angle. We have listened this afternoon to the fact that basically the bill reduces the tax-free thresholds for goods imported by mail or courier from $40 to $20. We all support that. I would like to go back to a committee meeting we had earlier today in industry and trade where the minister of tourism talked to us about the new Travel Canada campaign. In the course of his explaining the campaign to us, he brought to our attention that Canadians spend annually a little over $15 billion outside the country. I think approximately two-thirds or $11 billion is spent in the United States. Over all we have a current account tourism deficit in this country of close to $7 billion.
We have from a scenic point of view, from a cultural point of view and historic point of view great cities. We
Government Orders
have one of the greatest tourism assets anywhere in the world. Yet we are sitting here with a $7 billion deficit.
When I look at this amendment to the customs legislation I see that the government is trying to address but a small aspect of the problem we are having with cross-border shopping. I agree with the Minister of State for Finance and Privatization that cross-border shopping is a complex issue; it is not simple. When I pull myself back and I see a $7 billion tourism deficit, I have to say to myself that there is a much deeper problem.
When the minister of tourism appeared before a committee today, he announced this new Travel Canada campaign which we on this side of the House support and wish him well with. The problem is that it is only $3 million. First he said that it was the first time that a national minister of tourism had put forward a Travel Canada campaign.
We are talking about a sector of our economy that is the second largest employer in the nation. We are also talking about a sector, tourism, that has the ability to make us feel good about our country because the interaction on tourism, whether it is going out to dinner or going fishing in some other part of the country or skiing or travelling north, we are talking about an instrument that can build a terrific sense of pride, a terrific sense of national unity.
We are spending $3 million to handle a sector where there is $15 billion being exported; $3 million to try to handle a sector where there is a $7 billion deficit. That is part of the reason why we have so much cross-border shopping. Yes, it is our tax regime, especially the GST, which is a disincentive to a lot of Canadians. That poorly designed GST came at a time when so many people right across this country were in deep economic pain and that GST exacerbated the problem.
We should pull back a little from the tax complexities and the tax designs which need to be reformed in this country and think about the bigger picture. We do not do enough in the tourism sector to pump up this country. We do not do enough to pump this country to ourselves. We certainly do not do enough to pump Canada to the Americans coming here. We are conscious of using taxpayers' money, but we know historically that the return on tourism dollars has never failed this country.

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
The return on tourism dollars is one of the greatest returns of any taxpayer's dollar ever spent.
Rather than sort of tampering with our Customs Act-and I give the minister marks for doing this, but it is only a band-aid-I think we should be spending $40 million or $50 million encouraging Canadians to spend some of that $15 billion at home. When those dollars are spent at home there will be more people working. This means there would be less of a draw on the unemployment insurance fund. There would be less of a draw on the welfare fund. Therefore we would not need to tax people the way we do right now.
We have a proven asset with tourism. We know that a vibrant tourism economy will create jobs immediately and will create cash flow immediately. On top of all that, at this point in time when our national will or our national spirit is so fragile what better time to make Canadians feel good about their country.
I live in a riding in downtown Toronto which has three main streets. There are really four main streets but the businesses on three of them depend on tourism. Along the Danforth I have close to 150 of some of the nicest Greek, Chinese, Italian and Vietnamese restaurants. I have a beautiful group of Chinese restaurants along Gerard Street and I have a similar group along Queen in the south end of my riding. When those restaurants are filled and there are line-ups one can almost feel the spirit or the confidence of the community coming back. That spirit has a rub-off effect in terms of the sports stores, the clothing stores, the jewellery stores, or whatever other retail operations are in the community. We can feel it, not to mention jobs for summer students, jobs for students in the evening or jobs for students on the weekends.
When I see this bill today changing customs legislation and reducing the taxes on parcels being sent to us, I say it is fine. It is certainly a good deal for the post office. My goodness, $5 every time an invoice is checked. The minister said earlier there were seven million parcels to check. That is $35 million a year in revenue just for checking invoices. Good for the post office. I applaud its business acumen.
We are avoiding, not addressing, the main issue here. The reason why we have people flocking to the states to
the tune of billions and billions of dollars a year is that our tourism mechanism is not working.
I for one have great respect for the Minister of State for Tourism, this minister from London. He is dedicated to the file but he is one voice in that Cabinet. I remember when I was here in 1980-1984 working for Prime Minister Trudeau. Even then we tried to sell the idea of let us pump tourism and it was a tough sell then. But now, when we have such a rush on cross-border shopping, when we have such a deficit, we have to come to the support of the tourism sector in this country. We have to give it more money to promote the merits of travelling in Canada.
We cannot just link the importance of travelling in Canada to its beauty, to our cultural heritage, to our history or to our cities. We have to link the importance of travelling in Canada to the entire community. We have to link it to jobs. It is jobs for our students. It is jobs for our people.
If our work force is mobilized again, as I said before that will reduce the costs or change the design of our tax regime. This will mean there will not be a great temptation to run off to Buffalo for a $3 bottle of vodka, a $3 package of cigarettes or a cheap hotel room.
We have the finest tourist operators anywhere in the world. When people come to our country from Japan, Germany, England, France or the United States they think our country is one of the greatest tourism spots in the world.
In fact, with the little advertising we give our tourism sector we are still the eighth most visited country in the world. Can we imagine what another $40 million or $50 million in tourism promotion could do for us? No one in this country could ever question that tax expenditure because the money would come back instantly, not to mention the galvanizing effect it would have.
If there is one thing we need in this country right now, it is to feel good about everything we have, to feel good about everything we are enjoying. We should do a little less tinkering with some of our legislation. We should take a macro-economic look at our department of tourism and give it the resources it needs so that over the next 90 to 120 days every restaurant, hotel room and tourist operator in this country receives a flood of tourists from all over the United States, the same way Buffalo and other border states have received us during the last six months.
May 13, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I rise to take part in this debate. This is a very simple bill. It is a bill that says the government wants to reduce the mail order section of the Excise Tkx Act from $40 to $20 and it wants to penalize anyone whose mail order is over $20 by putting a set amount on that mail order. By the same token if somebody wants to send a gift into Canada, it goes from $40 to $60.
I am not against cross-border shopping. I am not against mail order. I am not against the gifts being higher. What I am against is the fact that we are not on a level playing field with the Americans.
I say that for several reasons. In the last year we have had GST put on everything in Canada from meals to cigarettes and goods made in the U.S. that come to Canada duty-free. As I say, we do not have a level playing field but we have many border towns. We have the largest border in the world with a very friendly neighbour. We have towns within about 125 miles of the border. We have 80 per cent of Canadians living near border towns. Therefore it is unreasonable for the government to continue maintaining a goods and services tax at the expense of all those companies that are going bankrupt, closing their doors because they have no sales. We see mail order companies like Sears reducing its services in Halifax and many jobs being lost.
Yet since May 81 have seen two things the government has done to try to stimulate Canadians. It had an ad in the papers saying: "Canada, 125 years, Buy Canadian". I think it is the government; it is somebody. It is a little late to be buying Canadian when most of what we are selling is coming from the States.
It would be better to say that we are going to give Canada a new deal, that we are going to start looking at our research and development, and that we are going to start looking to see what we can do to sell into the United States in a much greater capacity than we have done in the last few years.
That is not the vision this government has. It says that the goods and services tax stays, except for here and there. According to The Financial Post the net income of
Government Orders
Canadian families has taken a fall. This was 1990 that it looked at. It did not look at 1991 or the first part of 1992 when on top of everything else we have had the goods and services tax. It said: "After tax family income was lower in 1990 than in 1980 when the effects of inflation are removed. The average family earned $42,159 in 1980, compared to $41,434 in 1990. Between 1985 and 1990 income rose 2.7 per cent". Then it went on to say that Statistics Canada's survey of consumer finances found that income taxes took up almost 20 per cent of family income in 1990, up from 15 per cent in 1980.
"The income tax take has been steadily rising throughout the 1980s," the agency noted. It also reported that: "Canadian families paid an average of $10,199 in taxes in 1990 from $7,684 in 1990 dollars in 1980".
If you add to that the GST and the fact that that 80 per cent of Canadians live within 125 miles of a U.S. border town, you would have to ask yourself: "Why would a Canadian not go across the border to shop?" You would have to be crazy to think that they would not when you add our GST on top of what should be a level playing field, including a provincial sales tax.
It seems to me that the government would be far better off, instead of trying to keep the GST on so many goods, to lift the GST and allow some of those goods that would have a level playing field be the same here in Canada as they would be there if they were American-made and the duty was off. That is since the free trade agreement. The idea people have is that: because of the free trade agreement, it must be cheaper to go and shop there. They do not realize that if it was made in the U.S. it should be the same price here, but the GST and the provincial sales tax raises prices and there may be other reasons, such as the Canadian dollar.
Unless this government starts looking at that type of measure we are going to continue to have cross-border shopping. Reducing the exemption from $40 to $20 for a mail order is still going to take jobs from companies like Sears Canada which cannot compete because of all the taxes that the government takes.

May 13, 1992
Government Orders
This is a trickle down effect. Whether it is transportation costs or gas to bring the goods into Canada, it goes all the way through. The GST was just a killer on a declining family income when income taxes are taking more and more of the family income.
The government has had to correct it because it has seen what has happened to places like Sears. It has also said that now anyone can go there and buy up to $60 and have it sent as a gift. You just have to have somebody in the States who is going to say: "Gift?", and it comes in at $60. They do not pay GST, they do not pay any provincial sales tax. If it happens to be a state that does not have any state tax then it comes in even cheaper.
I just cannot understand a government that, on one hand, maintains the GST as a disadvantage, our take-home pay has been falling behind, and yet it says: "This week buy Canada", when 80 per cent of Canadians live within 125 miles of the U.S. border.
I come from a tourism area. Therefore, I will go one step further and say that it insults me as a Canadian to see the Minister of Tourism introduce a program of $3 million. I am not insulted at the partners who took part in that program, I think the partners in that group were Saga, Air Canada and Cook. I do not want to go on and name partners, but they are putting something into it too because they feel that they should, for Canada.
Our biggest industry is Americans who come to Canada. I do not see why this government, and Americans can get a rebate in certain areas, could not give Americans as they came in a card that would say: "This makes me exempt from paying the GST in Canada". The fact that they have to pay the GST on everything is a negative and as a result we are not getting the tourists into Canada.
At the same time, we have a $3 million program to try to keep Canadians in Canada. It does not make sense. I cannot see the sense of it. I would think that Canadians are probably going to stay in Canada this year because incomes are down, their jobs are gone and they do not have much hope from this government that things are going to improve because of the direction it is going.
I would think that the Canadians who will tour in Canada are going to be looking for the best deals. That means probably going across the border to shop because there is no GST, or if they cannot go across the border using mail order.
It is a little late for this government to be correcting something that it should never have introduced in the first place. Second, it is a little late to be correcting a mail order regulation when it should have thought before introducing it that Canadians were going to use mail order.
I have to go home tonight and I know I will have one or two of the booklets, maybe from L. L. Bean or Land's End, which are flocking in, along with other things in my mail. They want me to buy their product which normally, without the GST or the provincial sales tax or the transportation charges, would be the same price because it has been made in the U.S. and brought into Canada.
Like everything else it takes this government two years to realize the effect it has had. This government has literally taken all the will, all the hope from Canadians because it has not stimulated the economy. It does not look as if it is doing it, even though the recession appears, or so we are told because it is an election year in the United States, to be ending in the United States, which should affect us. I cannot see it because I see stores that are closed, I see hundreds of jobs gone in my constituency that will not be there afterward. Those people will have to move.
I see the fishery in such a state that I cannot believe. In a short period it has gone from the fishermen directing it to the companies. I see a tourism industry that used to be bountiful, used to bring a lot of jobs, create a lot of jobs, bring a lot of tourists and American dollars into Nova Scotia, particularly my constituency, South West Nova, via the ferry from Yarmouth to Bar Harbour and the ferry from Yarmouth to Portland. I do not see that. I do not know how much longer we can live with the GST on those visitors coming into Canada.
I would suggest that maybe the government come up with some idea rather than this $3 million program to send Canadians who probably do not have the money to travel across Canada but perhaps have enough money to go across the border. I would suggest that it start looking at the GST on some of the goods that these people go to the United States to buy and could buy here. I would suggest that the government look to see if it cannot bring in some type of program under which American tourists have a card given to them when they come in at the border and are told: "If you show this you will not pay
May 13, 1992

the GST in Canada". If they do not show it then it is their fault.
I would also suggest that being a gas-producing country where gas is so much cheaper-you just have to look at Irving which sells it in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia and then go to Maine and see Irving in Maine. It is all taxes-GST, provincial sales tax, plus the taxes that are put on gas to begin with.
This government must wake up and realize that it has overtaxed people to a point which has forced them to cross-border shop, to a point where they have no desire to shop in Canada and they will go to the U.S. to shop. It has overtaxed people to the point that there is not enough income to shop any more in Canada. We are draining the initiatives of all these people who are in service sectors in Canada because of a poor policy.

Mr. Speaker, I want to compliment my colleague on her remarks. I know that her tourism community is in deep pain right now because of the lack of real aggressive promotion in encouraging people to come to this country.
I want to refer back to an incident that happened, I think it was in 1984 during the Anti-Inflation Board, when a group of public officials went out and investigated different companies. With regard to this particular company they said: "Listen, you are making so much money that we want you to roll your prices back". The company went along with the rollback. It found that by rolling the prices back that it actually increased its business activity.
The intention of this amendment is to create a more level playing field and not put us at a disadvantage, to reduce cross-border shopping. My concern is that there is a possibility that we may have exacerbated the problem. When you change the threshold you might create such a level of awareness in the actual process that you will actually get a lot more people participating in this type of shopping arrangement.
In other words, the attention we are giving this issue is going to create a whole new type of shopping between
Government Orders
countries. Many people will find ways of getting around the price structure. Ultimately, without intention, we may be creating a whole new industry that never existed before.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the hon. member for his question. I think I know what he is getting at. It is the awareness that as we talk about cross-border shopping people will wonder what it is about and then go and find out that they can save, particularly as it relates to the 7 per cent GST and perhaps a sales tax. They might discover that if they take an overnight trip to the States, shop, and stay in a hotel and it will not cost nearly as much as staying here.
When you start digging around you will find out that there is a provincial sales tax, the GST, taxes on the gas, and taxes on food when you go out to eat. All those things come together to give the impression, and it is not an impression but a reality for some people, that it is cheaper to go the 125 miles because that is what 80 per cent of Canadians have to do.
Over and above that there are so many Canadians who are now spending so much time during the winter months in the United States that we now hear people saying: "I am going to wait until I go to the States to buy the things I want that I would have otherwise bought here". That is again to avoid the GST and the sales tax and the transportation costs. Those things even themselves out in terms of costs.
Coming from an area near New Brunswick, where you hear a lot about people going over the border just to buy groceries and things like that, it is a reality. It seems to cost less to buy chicken in Maine than it does in Canada. Canadians have always understood that there are costs to our jobs. What has happened with this government is that there is no understanding of the jobs involved or of the considerations. It has all gone out the window.
When you look at supply management at GATT and the efforts it has put in, which I do not think are good enough, or when you look at the GST as compared to what you can buy in the United States, Canada is not in a level playing field with the Americans. That is an awareness that I do not think talking about it relates. It is a reality when you live that close to the border and you see somebody across from you being able to buy some-

May 13, 1992

thing for their children and it costs you anywhere from 7 to 17 per cent more here in Canada. That is a reality.
The problem is taxes. We should be saying that we are going to remove the taxes and get people working again and get our industries back. We are not doing that. It is all negative. We do not have the income which was growing in the 1980s but is not growing now. On top of that, when we look at the 1990s, we see a 20 per cent federal tax on family income. That income is lower than in 1980. In 1991 and 1992 with the 7 per cent GST coming on top of that, Canadians have far less. There are no bargains apparently for Canadians in Canada because they are taxed.
I think that is why we have the cross-border shopping. Until we find a government that is going to look at some of these individual cases, give American tourists a card to exempt them so that tourists will come and we will have jobs in tourism, rather than the reverse of going downhill, we just will not win. We do not seem to have a government that comes up with any new ideas.

speakeroldname: Ms. Barbara Greene (Don Valley North) moved
speechtext:
that Bill C-235, an act to amend the Criminal Code (offences of sexual nature), be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
She said: Mr. Speaker, this bill is intended to address some of the particular ways in which victims of sexual assault experience violence at the hands of the judicial system.
May 13, 1992

Clauses 1, 2 and 3 will require judges to inform the complainants and the accused of their right to apply for the exclusion.
Clause 4 of the bill attempts to give great priority to the victims' safety and piece of mind by requiring the accused persons to establish why they should not be detained in custody until the conclusion of the judicial proceedings.
When women and, indeed, men and children are sexually assaulted and personally violated, the trauma, the pain and the fear they experience continues often for the rest of their lives.
Fewer than 40 per cent of female sexual assault victims and less than half of wife assault victims even report these crimes. Studies show that the reluctance to report is related to fear of retaliation that would result in further violence or death, lack of confidence in the police and the courts, guilt and embarrassment.
Women who are abused by a man with whom they are in an intimate relationship typically suffer from low self-esteem, fear, loss of control and isolation. They internalize blame and minimize the impact of the violence. They perceive that they have limited options for setting their lives on a new course, and their negative self-worth keeps them dependent and passive.
Women who have been sexually assaulted are approximately five times more likely to have a nervous breakdown, six times more likely to attempt suicide and eight times more likely to commit suicide or die prematurely.
An Ontario study of randomly selected women over 18 living with a male partner showed that physical and sexual violence against women and children causes emotional trauma that leads to alcohol and drug abuse by the victim as a means of easing the physical and emotional pain.
Compared to women who have not been physically or sexually abused as adults, 40 per cent more battered women report using drugs to sleep and 74 per cent more battered women report using drugs to relieve anxiety. Sexually assaulted women are two and one half times more likely than other women to use drugs to help them
Private Members' Business
sleep and nearly four times as likely to use drugs to combat anxiety.
A recent study of women who are in psychiatric wards in Toronto general hospitals reveals that 90 per cent of them had suffered from severe sexual and/or physical abuse in their childhood.
Sexual assault is very different from other assaults. It is violence which intends to degrade, humiliate and intimidate. Far too often, the judicial system also degrades, humiliates and intimidates women, and does not protect them.
It is clearly evident that many professionals including police, lawyers and judges fail to understand the pain that victims of sexual assault experience through the court and judiciary. The report The War Against Women by the status of women committee documents many examples. Indeed, as a former municipal politician and a teacher, I personally know many victims who have had devastating impacts on their lives.
The experience of one of my own constituents was what prompted me to produce this particular bill, which I first brought forward in 1989. My constituent is a slim, fragile woman in her sixties who is a former part-time school secretary. She is divorced and living on a modest income from the proceeds of the sale of her home in a quiet neighbourhood in a nice apartment building which has a lot of seniors living there.
She was sexually assaulted in the garage. She was one of eight women who were mostly elderly, but included a 16-year-old, who were viciously sexually assaulted and/ or raped by a brutal young man. He was caught by a young woman who heard the screams of his last victim and was charged, but swiftly released on bail.
At the preliminary hearing, my constituent and several other victims who were able to testify, testified. My constituent did this willingly, but was totally unprepared for the brutal interrogation by the defence lawyer which followed. All the victims were similarly treated.
The prosecutor did not apply for the exclusion of the public, and my constituent and the other witnesses were never informed of their rights to apply for a private hearing. Of course, as a courteous, dignified and law-

May 13, 1992
Private Members' Business
abiding citizen, she did not expect to be treated in such a vicious way.
The judge and the Crown allowed this to happen. When she turned to the judge seeking help, he had fallen asleep during my constituent's testimony. Following this devastating experience, my constituent's psychiatrist sent a letter saying that she could not testify again, but would be willing to sign an affidavit.
In spite of repeated inquiries, my constituent heard nothing further for years. Only recently has she discovered that the charges against a man who had raped or sexually assaulted eight women were dropped. Perhaps it is part of the actions following the Supreme Court decision regarding a backlog in the Ontario courts, but she does not know. She has no desire to revisit the experience and is not pursuing the matter. She has had enough of the courts. She is still experiencing fear, sudden pain, sudden rushes of terror and paranoia which cause her to be unable to leave her apartment or go into the garage by herself.
The lack of information to witnesses by the police, the brutal questions of the defence lawyer, the lack of sensitivity by the prosecutor, the doziness of the judge, the appalling injustice of this are all issues that need to be addressed but are difficult to legislate. One thing can be addressed and that is to at least let victims know their rights to greater privacy.
The second part of my bill deals with putting the onus on the accused to establish why he should not be detained in custody until the conclusion of the judicial proceedings.
One of the most common complaints of victims is that they are deeply afraid of their assailants. We have seen time after time that dangerous people are released. My constituent still lives in terror of her assailant.
Jonathon Yeo was allowed bail. Victims of wife assault frequently live in terror of their abusive husbands. They lay charges only to find their assailant is back at their door.
As a former municipal politician, I have had women approach me seeking protection and I have been unable to help them. If violent offenders are suspected of being a threat to any person they should not be allowed out of custody and the onus should be on them, not the overburdened Crown, to prove they are not a threat.
In conclusion, these are two measures which I believe will improve the situation for sexual assault victims. I
understand the minister supports the measures in principle but would like them to apply more narrowly than to fall on all the types of offences identified in section 274.
I would be willing to accept such amendments and would therefore request that the subject matter of the bill be referred to the justice committee for consideration and possible amendment before it is brought back to the House.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak to this bill brought by the hon. member for Don Valley North with mostly supportive responses. I would like to bring up a few points that may be dealt with if the bill is to be referred to the justice committee.
Under existing criminal law, under the amendments proposed by this bill, parties involved in a criminal trial do not have a right to have the public excluded from the court room. Public exclusion comes about only as the result of a judicial order. Exclusion orders are provided for in section 486 of the Criminal Code and they are permissive, meaning the judge or justice has discretion over whether or not the public can be excluded.
There is good reason for this because the history of a public trial is part and parcel of not just our democratic system but the adage that is still very true that "justice must not only be done, it must be seen to be done".
However, there is reason for exclusion of the public for a variety of reasons, many of which are germane to the kinds of cases my colleague has referred to in her remarks, particularly matters of a sexual nature; sexual assault, matters relating to children and so on.
The right of the accused and the prosecutor under section 486(2) of the Criminal Code is the right to apply for a judicial order for public exclusion and the right to be informed of the reasons if the judge or justice declines to issue the exclusion order. Clause 1 in Bill C-235 would extend this right to the complainant and provide for a right to be informed of the right to make an application for public exclusion.
By virtue of sections 486(3) and 486(4) the complainant has the right to make an application for a publicity ban on identity and the right to be informed of this right. Although it is true the exclusion of the public from the court room and a ban on publicizing the identify are not synonymous, there are certain similarities that I suspect might again provide for many of the things that the hon. member is looking for. Again I applaud her decision to refer this to the justice committee. We should have the
May 13, 1992

justice committee review all these sections together, look at exactly what it is the hon. member is trying to achieve, what we would certainly support her in attempting to achieve, and perhaps forge new sections of the Criminal Code that would be quite specific, clearing out one area of detritus if you will, and giving us the kind of specific to the offence situation that we are concerned about.
I would merely make a comment here in the need as evinced by the hon. member to support the wishes of complainants in matters relating to such sensitive areas as sexual assault.
We are all aware of the case that took place in Toronto not too long ago where a judge extended the publication ban and indeed a gag order on the complainants themselves who were victims of incest. The perpetrator was duly convicted. The complainants, the victims of the crime, wished to go public about their experiences. I do not know if I have their motivation absolute but one presumes it is a combination of the wish to educate and inform and also a certain amount of catharsis and healing in the same process, and they are forbidden to do so.
I think we might also, if the hon. member were willing, look at that aspect of publication bans and public exclusion.
I might add that the other problem under the section I mentioned is that the complainant does not have the right to be informed of the reasons why the judge or justice declined to order a publication ban. That too, I think, is a right that a complainant should have.
It is true that the hon. member and I come from metropolises of quite different sizes within the judicial system. The criminal justice system, in particular in my province, because of people knowing each other better tends to be perhaps more co-operative than in the larger city where people do not know each other so well. Obviously law cannot depend upon the societal and social relationships of the participants.
I would therefore support most strongly the hon. member's intentions and her recommendation that the
Private Members' Business
bill be sent forward to the justice committee. I would hope that when that happens the hon. member and I will both find ourselves at the justice committee where we can further discuss this matter and come up with the kinds of amendments that will enhance the situation.
With regard to the further sections of the act proposed by the hon. member, I certainly would support them and will recommend to my caucus that support be forthcoming as well.

Mr. Speaker, I rise as justice critic for the New Democratic Party to respond to this private member's initiative. It is a very interesting bill and a good initiative.
I want to congratulate the member for Don Valley North. She is, as you know, Mr. Speaker, and this House knows, a fighter for women's issues and she constantly plugs away at these matters and it comes from the heart. You can see it.
That is why when the member brings in a bill, it is really worth considering and worth looking at. I congratulate her for her bill and I know she will continue to plug away on these particular issues.
I want to say a couple of general things before going into the member's bill specifically. The bill is good in a general sense, in that it gives victims some power, some access to the judicial system. This is what has been lacking in our judicial system in my view and I think in the view of the hon. member.
Sometimes the victim who becomes the witness in the criminal proceeding, the complainant, is treated by the prosecution, and indeed by the judge and even by the whole court system, as the accused. We tend to forget who the accused is. The victim leaves the court process, as many witnesses do, with a bad taste in his or her mouth. Often it is her because it seems to apply especially to women victims and especially in the area of sexual assaults. We all know it is hard enough to get complainants in sexual assault cases to go to court to make the complaint and then get it into court without having all the difficulty that the people have when they get to court.

May 13, 1992
Private Members' Business
I know the government has brought in a lot of justice bills recently. It calls them law and order. I call them lawn ornaments. I feel they have been bills that have responded to the Supreme Court decisions which have overturned laws of this country because of the charter of rights or they have dealt with things in a general way.
When I saw the Minister of Justice appear before the justice committee yesterday on the estimates, I found that she was great at intellectualizing. She is great at talking this broad picture, but when it really comes down to how the system of justice works for real people I feel she should get herself into a court, get herself down there and maybe have a look at how things really work.
Let me deal with the bill. There are basically two parts to the bill of the member for Don Valley North, as I see it. The first clause is the explanation and it reads:
This amendment would provide the opportunity to the complainant to apply for the exclusion of the public during judicial proceedings; at present, only the prosecutor and the complainant are afforded that opportunity. The new subsection (2.01) would require the presiding judge to inform the complainant and the accused of their right to apply for the exclusion.
That seems to me to be good. I would like to hear all the arguments and that is why I would like to see it referred to the justice committee. I think the hon. member has made a good suggestion on the general principle of the bill. It seems to me that this is a fair procedure and it requires the judge to say: "Hey, you have that right and you can do that". I think that is important. The reason it is in there is so that we can get more complainants, especially women, in sexual assault cases.
I heard the debate in the House. It was a stunning debate, a great debate in the House of Commons when we debated on principle the rape shield bill. We heard from all over the House of Commons, especially from women members of the House of Commons, how serious this situation was. They recounted case after case of women who had been assaulted usually through the family, I am afraid to say, or through people they knew. We heard about the violence and so on and about the difficulty of bringing this out in public, never mind getting it into the judicial system.
It seems to me that this is a good amendment. The first clause is going in the right direction. The second clause I have a little bit more difficulty with. It is basically clause 4 of the bill. Two and three are consequential amendments to the first part. Clause 4 is separate. Clause 4, the explanation of the bill, says:
The new section 522.1 would put the onus on the person accused
of an offence of a sexual nature to establish that he should not be
detained in custody until the conclusion of the judicial proceedings.
Section 522.1 is the section of the Criminal Code that will be put in there if this bill passes.
One can see the problem. There was a recent case where a woman did everything she was supposed to do in our present judicial system and she ended up getting killed. She was murdered. She complained against her husband. She made all the proper complaints to the police. They were separated. She went to court. He was pulled in court. He was released. She said she was in danger and she was; he came back and killed her.
Fortunately that does not happen in many cases. It is the exception rather than the rule. I say it is an exception. I mean you do not release people and they go out and murder their wives.
Don't play with your statistics, Ian.
In my experience it has been.
There were 17 cases in Nova Scotia in one year.

My friend said there were 17 cases in Nova Scotia in one year. I am open to hearing that. In my experience as a Crown attorney and as a defence counsel it seemed to me that it was rare. It happened and it was a tragedy when it happened. I will hear that, I hope, in the committee.
The point I want to go back to is bail because this deals with bail. In the bad old days, I will call them before the Bail Reform Act in the seventies, people who were accused had to make bail. Many poor people could not find money for bail and they were locked up, unnecessarily in my view. The test was whether they would come back to court for their trial. People were locked up. We had a system of bail bondsmen and so on. A lot of people spent more time in custody awaiting their trial than they did even if they were convicted after a trial. It was a bad system.
May 13, 1992

When the system was reformed and changed there was a lot of reaction against it. It was tough to get that reform through. Police forces and other groups said: "You are just letting these crooks out on the street". It was hard to make that reform, but I think we have come to the point now where the new bail reform system has been generally accepted. Some people still complain, but it is generally accepted. It is basically a good system, a very progressive system that puts Canada in a good light.
I am concerned that if we put the onus on the person accused of the offence to explain why he should get out of custody, we are in fact beginning to dismantle the progressive bail reform laws. That is my concern.
I understand the difficulties. I understand what the hon. member is trying to do. As I understand it, she wants to improve the help to a sexual assault victim and improve the way that situation is dealt with. There might be other ways of doing that. Judges have to be more aware of the situation. Judges have to be educated in the facts of what is happening out there in the world with respect to sexual assaults against women and violence against women. The prosecutors have to be educated. In some ways we are doing that as we get more and more equality and as we get more and more women prosecutors in the process, more and more women judges, and some other judges getting judicial education.
The public has to be educated and the public is being educated. The member for Halifax a moment ago was telling me that I should know a little bit more about the number of murders committed by people in a family violence situation who were released after being charged. The public is being educated and getting more educated. I think we are on the right track there.
I draw the Chair's attention to the debate in the House on the rape shield bill. But I say this: In correcting one wrong let us not create another wrong. That is my concern about the second part of the bill.
I do not have a concern about the first part of the bill. I think it is a good idea. The member for Don Valley North suggested that this bill be referred in principle,-I gather the subject matter,-to the justice committee
Private Members' Business
because we are considering a number of bills and laws on this veiy nature. There is a real momentum in the House of Commons at this particular time in our history to face the issue of violence and violence against women.
We are proud of Canada for generally being a safe and non-violent society, but it is too violent in certain areas. We have to tackle that and I believe we are prepared to do that.
I will sit down, shut up and hope that the government will allow this bill to be referred in principle to the justice committee. Again I congratulate the hon. member for Don Valley North on her effort in this bill.

speakeroldname: Mr. Rob Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to join my colleagues in congratulating the member for Don Valley North on bringing this bill and this subject before the House of Commons.
Like the last speaker, I am very pleased that the bill begins by talking about victims. A trend we have seen in the last couple of years, particularly with legislation that has been brought before this House, is the idea that the judicial system has to look after everyone's rights, including victims.
It is interesting that just yesterday, in changes to the Parole Act, the Solicitor General referred to provisions within that bill which give more rights to victims. So for the second day in a row I welcome the fact that Parliament is again discussing the subject of victims.
As was pointed out, the bill touches on a number of different areas. The member for Don Valley North made the case very powerfully in terms of what happens to people who get caught up within the judicial system, particularly women, because women are the victims of the vast majority of sexually related crimes.
It is an important subject and I have to disagree with the last speaker to a certain extent when he said that we are preoccupied with bills relating to lawn ornaments. I do not agree with that. We have passed some very important legislation that touches on the rights of individuals.

May 13, 1992
Private Members' Business
The gun control bill is a substantial and important piece of legislation, one that I think brings about considerable improvement within that particular area. And this is an area of concern. The hon. member herself pointed out that very often when crimes are committed with a firearm women are the victims.
These are not lawn ornaments; these are substantial pieces of legislation. With the rape shield law, again in the same area the member has raised this evening, on the question of how women in particular are treated within the judicial system, what is necessary to obtain a conviction for those who commit rape and other serious crimes? It is important legislation for all Canadians and one that all members of Parliament can take a great deal of pride in, because it is a good piece of legislation and one that helps.
Just a few years ago when we made changes to the law as it relates to children testifying in court, some of the rules of evidence as they relate to children went back at least a century, if not two centuries. I think they were founded on some wrong assumptions as to the way children behaved. But I was very pleased that we were making changes in the Criminal Code, ones that are a little more sensitive to children, who are very often the victims of sexual violence.
I do share some of the concerns that the hon. member who just spoke had regarding the bail provisions. The bail provisions, as I read them in this act, cast a very wide net. The hon. member alluded to the fact that perhaps the whole area could be narrowed to get at what it is she would like this House to deal with.
As it would stand now in this particular piece of legislation, the bail provisions as they relate to the most serious crimes in society, specifically murder and treason, would apply to, for instance, an offence of nudity. I do not think that is exactly what the hon. member wants to get at. I think she wants to narrow it to those most serious offences of sexual assault. But, as I say, the way it is worded now it casts a wide net.
It would be a helpful suggestion for this matter to be referred to the Standing Committee on Justice and the
Solicitor General. As I said, I was interested to hear the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam who sits on the justice committee. It is a demonstration of good faith in getting this matter discussed before the committee that he has indicated he is prepared to spend his time and to urge committee members to take up this matter.
Heaven knows, they have a lot to do at the present time, but this too is important.
I commend the hon. member who has had in her three and a half years in this House a record of sticking up for those who get caught up in the judicial system, who are victims, she wants to see changes in the laws to make sure that the laws of this country are fair to them as well as to the accused and others who are involved in the judicial system.
I commend her for that. I hope the House takes up the suggestion of referring the subject matter of her bill to the standing committee on justice.

Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I believe you will find that there is unanimous consent for the following motion:
That the bill be withdrawn, the order discharged and the subject
matter referred to the Standing Committee on Justice and the
Solicitor General.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Members have heard the terms of the motion. Is it agreed?

Agreed.
Order discharged, bill withdrawn, and subject matter referred to Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General.
